notes: No activity toward promotion. Not more than 25 homes. No realty activity in 6 or 7 years.
name: Richmond, Virginia

notes: This area is on the so-called "west side" not easy of access and has been slow in developing for that reason.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Well planned. Scenic features good. Overlooking Packard Park.
detr_influences: Churches, stores, schools, not conveniently near.

notes: Southeastern part of area older - poorly planned except North Todd which is good. Garden Street along R.R. has houses 50 years old poor to fair condition. New street in - not shown on map about 30 houses on this street.
source: W. E. Lynn
name: Warren, Ohio
desc_terrain: Level - higher than business district and the Mahoning Avenue side of the river
favor_influences: Some restrictions. Bus transport is regular (30 minute intervals)
detr_influences: No schools, no stores, no churches. Necessary to cross railroad to go into area.

notes: East of York Street nearly all American inhabitants
source: W.E. Lynn
name: Warren, Ohio
desc_terrain: Slopes slightly north from Railroad, otherwise level and high from east to west.
favor_influences: 5 Churches - 2 schools, nearby stores along W. Market, Parkman and Mason Streets. Transportation by bus along both north and south boundaries.
detr_influences: Concentration of negroes and foreign at western extremity on Nevada, Oregon and McNyler Streets. Commercial encroachment along W. Market and Summit Streets.

notes: about 6 very expensive homes along Mahoning at south end of area
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Adjacent to Packard Park. Roosevelt School in area.
detr_influences: Possible influx of lower grade population from C-6

notes: Good transportation, close to factories, school and churches also Fire Station in area.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Roosevelt School, 1 grade. Not far to factories. General Motors Plant, Ohio Lamp Factory, etc.

notes: Warren City Tank & Boiler Company has offices south central section of this area. Loan commitments about 20% of appraisals here. Area has slight tendency to increase of colored population.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Proximity to Packard. Sunlight Warren City Tank & Boiler Co. Grinnell Company, Youngstown Pressed Steel etc.
detr_influences: Very bad planning and poorly built homes

notes: Sunlight new plant (G.M.) will be built just north of this area.
source: W.E. Lynn
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Schools nearby in C-2 and C-7. Churches conveniently near in C-2. Walking distance of shopping center. Shade trees.
detr_influences: Proximity to R.R. and industry on north.

notes: Best section of area is at extreme west - Perkins Drive deserving Grade A but too small to be a separate area.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Close to city, fine shade trees, Central Jr. High School in area, churches, nearby shopping centers. Near the High School. Park adjacent to Perkins Circle.
detr_influences: None
build_type: 6-room singles; 10-15 rm old singles; Few converted duplex

notes: Some large houses used as rooming houses along Porter & High Streets. Many owners moved out and rented their houses - holding them for a rise because of business encroaching. Central Jr. High School in area, also St. Mary's Catholic School, Elm Road School.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
desc_terrain: Level with slight rise eastward on Market Street. Slight depression of land along the railroad between Chestnut and Linden. Near shopping districts, and within walking distance of Republic Mill. Grade School in area. Churches in area.
detr_influences: Encroaching business and industry.
build_type: 5-6 rm singles; Large old singles; Few apartments

notes: Foreigners likely to invade this area. Home Saving & Loan Companies of Youngstown, also Trumbull had about 50 foreclosures in this area which were offered for sale in October 1936. All closed out now. Prices Average 3500, the amount of the mortgage.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Schools in area. Close to High School in B4 area. Adjacent to factories (for those who work in factories)
detr_influences: Adjacent to Railroad and factories.

notes: This area has everything from abandoned homes at one time worth $100,000, to small homes worth $5,000. There are any number of apartment buildings anywhere from 3-family to 12-family apartments; will not sell on less than 25% gross return.
name: Richmond, Virginia
price1929: All mixed up. Values from $75,000 to $5000
currentprice: All mixed up. Values from $75,000 to $5000
lowprice: All mixed up. Values from $75,000 to $5000

notes: In 1929 this section was not so well developed as it is now. Also opening of Genessee Blvd. from E. Market to Elm Road and of Woodland Avenue to the Country Club has improved value in the area. The expensive houses in this area are generally along Fairmont & Bonnie Brae. Genessee.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: High school in area. Grade school across street from the area in C-7 (Elm Road School)
detr_influences: Fair grounds in center of area between Atlantic and Woodland Avenue.

notes: Slavish Catholic Church just out of the area at the northwest which may have tendency to concentrate Slavish into C-2 and thence into B-7
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: A good residential neighborhood, close to the business center. Community spirit evident. Double drive up Iddings. Known as Iddings Park.
detr_influences: None

notes: Paving assessments were high because of unnecessary expense of layout. In some cases the amount of special assessments exceed the price of the lot.
source: T. Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
desc_terrain: Level - few trees in eastern end but beautiful trees in western section.
favor_influences: Attractive planning - adjacent Country Club - best school in city. Transportation (every 30 minutes) by bus.
detr_influences: No stores convenient, no churches nearby.

notes: This is the very best blue section
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: School nearby in A-1 area. Transportation through area. Shade trees plentiful.
detr_influences: None

notes: Lots in this area are of good size. East Junior High School and Warren City Hospital in this area.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Grade school in area - churches - transportation through the area - bus line. Zoning restrictions.
detr_influences: None

notes: Rent decline due to improvidence of occupants. All work in Republic Steel, about 3 blocks away from the area.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
desc_terrain: Flat - lowest built up section of city.
favor_influences: Close to mill. Business center available. Schools near, within walking distance of shopping center.
detr_influences: Concentration of disorderly houses along Fulton Street. Heavy paving assessment on Fulton Street. So. Park Ave Walnut street. Low grade population.

notes: Not quite as good as D-1, 20% lower rentals, 50% lower sales values. City dump adjacent to this property on west. Dump between Hayden and Steele Sts.
source: Tome Boyle
name: Warren Ohio
favor_influences: Near Republic Steel Mill. Neighborhood stores.
detr_influences: Old property - Overflow at times of high water no schools.

notes: Section was built around old Western Reserve Steel Mill. This mill is gone now. This section probably worst in the city.
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
desc_terrain: Flat but high enough to be secure from floods
favor_influences: Air Reduction Sales Company. Chicago Car Roofing Co. One Steel Mill also in area. School but no churches. Bus transportation.
detr_influences: B&O Railroad & Earie R.R. pass through area. Some streets unimproved
build_type: 2 apt. houses in area 4-5-6 rm singles

notes: Section is "killed" by influx of negroes from D-3 to attend Francis Willard School in C-8
source: Tom Boyle
name: Warren, Ohio
favor_influences: Factories near northwest section of this area. Restrictions - zoning residential. School, some churches. Stores adjacent on Niles Road & Youngstown Road.

desirability: Static except in west extremity where possibly up.
notes: About 200 bungalows west of Austin. Todd Avenue out of city limits (south) good prospects for favorable development.
source: W.E. Lynn
name: Warren, Ohio
desc_terrain: Generally level with very slight slope toward river.
favor_influences: West side Jr. High School Palmyra & Austin, 3 churches. Neighborhood stores along Market, Highland Avenues. Quinby Park.
detr_influences: Southeastern portion of the area characterized by foreign and negro.
inhab_type: Factory workers, merchants and business men
pop_inc: High birth rate in S.E. part
build_age: West of Austin 12 yrs.; No. Central Sec 25 yrs.; S.E. Section 25 yrs.

desirability: Problematical - If restrictions are enforced as originally set out, trend of desirability will be upward.
notes: Information is that holding company has offered lake to city free, subject to conditions that city would maintain water at certain level in lake,etc., but offer has been withdrawn.  Abandonment of lake or its destruction will seriously affect values and desirability of this area.  The opinion was expressed that abandonment of lake would affect desirability of section and cause values to decline and likewise would lower tax assessments and for this reason lake would be maintained even though it was necessary for city to take it over.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative, and Hugh G. Hall, HOLC, Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city convenience - Golf Course - Mountain View - Swimming Pool - Lake - Adequate Bus Transportation.  Originally highly restricted.
detr_influences: About 85% undeveloped and several hundred vacant lots as well as adjoining acreage, golf course, lake and swimming pool are owned by holding company for defunct mortgage company which acquired property by foreclosure.  Sales program on vacant lots now getting under way but considerable speculation as to restrictions which will appear under the new program.
inhab_type: Executives and business men and Professional men.

notes: Southern part of area South and East of Golf Links is known as "Grove Park" and is about 90% built up with beautiful expensive homes predominating.  This part of the area is the older part but is still "tops".  The part of the area West of the Golf Links and Kimberly Avenue contains the lower prices properties.  All new construction is in that part of the area lying North of the Golf Links, this being the part more recently developed.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative, and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: Adjoins Asheville Country Club & Golf Course - Grove Park Inn, famous as one of the leading resort hotels in the country - Magnificent mountain view - Schools in area - adequate transportation - all city conveniences.  Parkways in middle of streets and grass plots on sidewalks maintained by "Grove Park" Park Commision with property owners assessed 10 cents per front foot for this maintenance.  Recognized as the most ideal spot around Asheville for the average business or professional man to reside.
detr_influences: None
inhab_type: Business Executives - Professional men and Capitalists
build_type: Large singles - a few higher-price apartments and duplexes

notes: That part of the area lying along Hendersonville Road, White Oak Road and Buena Vista Road contains the lower priced properties.  The remainder of this area contains nothing but higher priced properties.  It is an exclusive development joined on the North, West and South by the Biltmore Estate, former home of George W. Vanderbilt, deceased, containing 12,000 acres and the famous Biltmore House.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: Highly restricted residential area and restrictions strongly enforced.  All city conveniences except gas.  Private country club with golf course located in area.  All residences are in higher-priced class.  Private bus transportation.
detr_influences: None except the fact that the Eastern side of Hendersonville Road is not restricted and there are small stores and tourist cabins located on that side, which adversely affects properties fronting on Western side of road.

notes: That part North of Edgewood is best part of area.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation close to community business center - schools - churches.  Only short distance to Beaver Lake Swimming Pool and Golf Course.
detr_influences: Encroachment of Tourist homes along Merriman Avenue, which is just East of the area.

notes: This area contains about a dozen houses, all large single family and expensive and misplaced.  Future development, if any, will probably be in the medium to lower priced range.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences - close to schools and colleges.
detr_influences: Railroad yards and roundhouses on Southwest - Inadequate transportation.  No restrictions.

notes: Area not restricted- general in type of property and development.  Good, bad and indifferent houses all over area.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences - adequate transportation - close to schools - churches and main business section.
detr_influences: On eastern side of area, (which is the foot of Sunset Mountain) are some obsolete tubercular sanitariums.  However, these buildings are gradually being razed and it will only be a short time until all are removed.
build_type: Small singles- some apartments and duplexes.

desirability: Working men's homes--cheap construction will decline
notes: Easternmost limits north of the park are $6,000 to $8,000 bricks; balance small frame bungalows called "chicken coops".
name: Richmond, Virginia
detr_influences: Abandoned quarry southeast oval "O"

notes: Montford Avenue at one time was one of the best residential streets in the city and there are many large, beautiful homes occupied by very substantial citizens.  Pearson Drive also has many large, expensive homes.  The trend, however, is not in this direction and while the area is still a very desirable place in which to live, the increasing age of the properties and encroachment into immediate adjoining areas of lower income group will eventually have a detrimental effect in this area.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: Close to center of city - all city conveniences - adequate transportation - parking area.
detr_influences: Age of properties - surroundings - hospital in area

desirability: Northern part upward - Southern part static to downward.
notes: Southern part of this area is known as "Old Kenilworth" and is about 80% developed.  Northern part is known as Kenilworth addition and Fountainbleau and is only about 10% developed.  Central Western portion is known as Forest Hills.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences - close to schools, churches and business center.  Adequate transportation.
detr_influences: Negro settlement in area - Sanitarium for those suffering nervous ailment, located on Caledonia Road (formerly Kenilworth Inn).  Smoke from railroad.
inhab_type: Professional men - Business men - Clerical - Railroad employees

notes: This is a fairly uniform section, small but decidedly superior to the surrounding areas.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: High School in area - All city conveniences - Adequate transportation.
detr_influences: Surrounded by cheap construction - area about 90% developed.

notes: This is a small section of uniform construction, much better than the surrounding area.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences - Restricted residential section - adequate transportation close by - not far distant to schools, churches and business center.
detr_influences: Nothing particular.
inhab_type: Business men - professional men, clerks - railroad men

notes: Along Heywood Road are several higher priced residences, and in other part of area construction is fairly uniform.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences - Restricted residential sections - Adequate transportation - close to schools, churches and business center.
detr_influences: Some distance to main business section - approach from East not good.
inhab_type: Executives of Enka Corporation, some business and professional men

desirability: Problematical - depending to a large extent on practice followed in disposing of vacant lots and what restrictions are maintained.
notes: The subdivision originally started by founder of Asheville School for Boys (an exclusive institution) with the idea in mind of selling the sites to former students for use as summer homes.  Ownership originally carried with it right to use school lake and golf course.  However, after spending his money he found it necessary to borrow to further the development and mortgage company foreclosed and now owns practically all of vacant property.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: Adjoining Golf Course - near Asheville School for Boys - All city conveniences except gas - Highly restricted subdivision.
detr_influences: Holding Company for defunct mortgage company owns most vacant lots and adjoining acreage and possibility of future development not being in line with present type of properties.  Somewhat isolated distance to schools and main business section.  Inadequate transportation.  Tourist camp on Haywood Road near Northwest corner of area.
salesdemand2: Nothing for sale except vacant lots and no demand for them

desirability: Northern part static - Southern part upward
notes: Vermont & Northern part of Brevard almost entirely developed.  Southern part only about 10% built up.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, Fee Property Appraiser.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences - Adequate transportation - not far distant to  school - Asheville Rhododendron Gardens adjoins Southern part of area.
detr_influences: Southern part of area slightly isolated and distant from school and community business facilities.
build_type: Small singles - some apartments and duplexes
build_age: 20 years on Vermont & Brevard - 10 years southern part.

notes: Industrial plants in the area employ practically all people living in it and their activity (uncertain with exception of the National Casket Company) governs activity in the area.  Majority of houses built when furniture factory established.  It has since closed and is now operated at intervals by the Alden Manufaturing Company (somewhat unstable) which manufactures an imitation antique furniture.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: School in area - all city conveniences except gas.
detr_influences: Outside city limits - inadequate transportation - no restrictions.  Industrial plants located in area.
pop_inc: Slowly due to increased industrial activity

rentdemand2: Apartments - Small singles, large singles for tourist purposes
notes: Along Merriman Avenue some large, expensive homes still occupied by owners, but great majority being turned into Tourist Homes by owners to increase income, or being purchased by others for this purpose.  Montford Avenue, formerly one of best residential streets in city.  Flint and Cumberland also good residential streets, but boarding and rooming houses are gradually encroaching.  Good negro section on Crescent, Madison and Lee, ten years ago occupied entirely by whites.  Also lower type negro section on Short Street and at North end of Flint St.  Business gradually expanding into this area on most every side of present main business district.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation, close to main business section, schools, churches, etc.
detr_influences: Merriman Avenue heavy traffic artery.  Encroachment of Tourist Homes and apartments.  Tuberculosis sanitarium on Barnard Avenue, Hospital on Woodfin.  Older type of properties. Boarding and Rooming houses in area.
infiltration: Negro slowly in area, around Crescent, Madison and Lee Streets.
build_type: Large and small singles, Duplexes - Apartments
salesdemand2: Large homes for use as tourist homes

notes: This is in what was formerly West Asheville, a separate incorporation.  It is necessary to cross River to get to it and Haywood Road is about the center of the area and along it, for approximately 1.5 miles, are many business places, from cheap to good, with centers at Haywood and Westwood and at Brevard Road and Haywood Road.  Very little development in extreme Western part.  Eastern boundary of area is a high bluff with river at bottom and on this side, north of Haywood Road, is some very, very cheap development.
source: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences - churches, schools, in area.  Adequate transportation on Haywood Road, which is almost in center of area.  Private bus line operates to Enka Corporation Plant about three miles from this area.
detr_influences: Distance to main business center not in line of future better development.  Large number of houses owned by lending agencies through foreclosure and other acquisition.  Hosiery mill in area.
inhab_type: Clerical - skilled mechanics.  Laborers and Industrial and Mill workers of Enka Corp.
build_type: Small singles - Some duplexes and apartments

notes: This area, though seemingly most desirable, is in conversion to rentals. Owners are moving west. Along Monument Avenue on both sides for 30 years has been concentrated the culture and wealth of Richmond. The peak has passed. Though this is a boulevard with a parked center and monuments to Confederate celebrities at important intersections, the offspring of these homes are moving west and 40% of reproduction cost would be hazardous in the event of acquisition. Too many three-story homes, high ceilings, high heating costs, obsolete. High reproduction costs. There are 2, 6, 12 and 24 family apartment buildings. Hospitals, churches, schools; big homes being converted to apartments.
name: Richmond, Virginia
inhab_type: Better people moving out--trades people moving in
build_type: Every conceivable type of brick houses; all mixed up
salesdemand2: $4,500 would be paid for a $50 rental houses

notes: Biltmore Station on Southern Railroad through northern part of this area was originally built by the Vanderbilts and around the station was built a business center, English Type, and many small English type pebble dash houses, 5 to 7 rooms, 1.5 to 2 story.  It was the entrance to the Vanderbilt Estate and something of a lobby, but the trend is definitely downward.  Across the Hendersonville Road, at the southwest corner of this area, is located Biltmore-Forrest Estates, which is a highly restricted subdivision.
source: William Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.
name: Asheville, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation.  Biltmore business center in area.  Schools and churches, also in area.
detr_influences: Railroad and River through northern part - large portion outside city limits.  Industrial plants in Northern part of area.  Subject to overflow in section close to railroad and Swannanoa River.  Sanitarium of Biltmore Road in extreme Northern part of area.
inhab_type: Bleachery workers - clerical mechanics - Railroad workers

notes: North end of Western side almost a mountain.  Southern side contains railroad depot, big negro bus district, and cheap houses. Eastern side very rolling.  Better part is that nearest main business district.
source: William Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.

detr_influences: Industrial plants along railroad tracks on western side of area.  Cheap construction, also filling stations and some cheap stores on Biltmore Road.  Also many business places in the part nearest main business district.

desirability: Almost bottom now - litle prospect for any better.

name: Richmond, Virginia
detr_influences: Apartments along the park front. Home for Incurables east of the park down at Powaton Street. 4-family flats on Rosewood Street. On Maplewood there are cheap frame bungalows near Meadow Street. Balance of this street going west fairly good single-family bricks.
build_type: All types of single-family homes; brick pre-dominates

notes: Old part of town in decline.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Old part of town in decline.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Old part of town in decline.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Old part of town in decline: "D" rating on Pierce St., 7th to 8th St.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

desirability: Will probably be still desirable for 10 years.
name: Richmond, Virginia
favor_influences: Desirable area

notes: Practically undeveloped and inaccessible; probably will develop "Red D". Vacant land.
source: J. D. Carneal
name: Richmond, Virginia

notes: Extreme West end of space between Reed St. and Lancaster St. adjoining Spring Hill Cemetery "D" rating
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Extreme West end of space between Reed St. and Lancaster St. adjoining Spring Hill Cemetery "D" rating
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: From Tazewell to Holliday "D" Rating.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Extreme West end of space between Reed St. and Lancaster St. adjoining Spring Hill Cemetery "D" rating
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Extreme West end of space between Reed St. and Lancaster St. adjoining Spring Hill Cemetery "D" rating
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Along Manfield St. Kenyon to Oakley Avenue, on the east end of Kenyon, along both sides of Centerdale St., there are about 35 new houses rating "B." From Oakley to Talbot and east of Talbot between Norma & Banker "D" rating. Allegheny Ave. Judith to Memorial "D" rating. Oakley Ave. is Commercial. Memorial Ave. Talbot to N. Grand, Stores.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia
black: Few in "D" ratings as per foot note

notes: Patrick St. to Munford "D" rating. From North Smith to North Bath for the full length of both Streets and full length of all Streets between them borderline "D" and "C" rating. Stores and shops are on Memorial Ave. Munford to Forrest St. The Area from Pollard and 4th, along Pollard to First, to York, to 2nd, to Chambers to 4th and back to Pollard "D" rating.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia
Lynchburg, Virginia
desc_terrain: Hilly - known as Fort Hill Addition

notes: Hazardous spots are shown in red.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: One-half of block east of Pierce from 17th to 18th "D" Rating.
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Houses facing Peakland Place are not up to "A" standard and rate "B"
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Houses facing Peakland Place are not up to "A" standard and rate "B"
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Houses facing Peakland Place are not up to "A" standard and rate "B"
name: Lynchburg, Virginia

notes: Strictly residential section. Properties along Roosevelt Blvd. have been built within past 10 years.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Emsworth
desc_terrain: Hilly - sloping up from Beaver Road.
favor_influences: Demand from R. R. Workers - good train transportation, street car and bus service, new blvd. into section. More ground around houses.

notes: Between Dickson & Western Ave. South of Church St. are houses ranging in price up to $50,000 averaging $20,000 - those lands are of considerable age but in good condition. Negro is confined to Olive Ave section.
source: W.A. Stachs
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Avalon
desc_terrain: Hilly - sloping up from the river - level at eastern end.
favor_influences: No flood hazard
detr_influences: Smoke & dirt & fog from river - mill in Neville island south of California gives off silt which blows into this section.

notes: All new construction built for specific individuals.  Large country club located here.  Atmosphere in general very good
source: W. A. Stoehr
name: Sub Pittsburgh - Ben Avon Heights
desc_terrain: Hilly - rolling territory on top of mound
favor_influences: Very desirable residential with high class populace.
detr_influences: Steep descent.  Only fair transportation.

notes: Neighborhood has some very large homes now converted to duplexes and rental units. Streets in good condition.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Bellevue
desc_terrain: Hilly, sloping up from Ohio River, very little level ground.
favor_influences: Good bus service - shopping center; good schools
detr_influences: Smoke, dirt, and fog from river and mills and factories on Neville Island.

notes: Certain portions of Danes Ave. Terman Ave. and Orchlee Avenues contain very fine homes up to $30,000 which have been built in past 18 months. Section is quite active.
source: W. A. Stoehr
name: Pittsburgh - No Side
favor_influences: Good transportation - relatively new territory good streets - property well designed and in good condition.
detr_influences: Obsolescence - Very spotty.
build_repair: Good on brick - Only fair on frame

notes: The northern section is an exclusive territory. Pride of ownership is very prevalent. Trend of development is due north. Some very good houses along Perrysville Ave. fronting on the Park.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Pittsburgh - no side
desc_terrain: Entire area is on high ground sloping on both sides
favor_influences: Good transportation. Near Park. Desirable residential section of modest character.
detr_influences: Spotty bad paving, some streets are steep.
inhab_type: Southern part - average type, white collared & executive type in northern part

notes: This is a larger territory, people are mortgage conscious in sections of Troy Hill, Spring Hill & Pineview, resulting in few foreclosures.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Pittsburgh, Troy Hill
desc_terrain: Very hilly, comprised of 4 separate hills and two valleys
favor_influences: Near to business section; transportation fairly good throughout.
detr_influences: Bad odor from disposal plant and stockyards, spotty.

notes: This is one of the older sections of Pittsburgh which is gradually being taken over for commerical purposes. Some 800 properties are reported condemned by the city. These were damaged by recent flood etc. Generally speaking this section is classed as the lower or undesirable type. Most of property located there can be purchased for ground value.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Pittsburgh, No side
desc_terrain: Low lying territory along Allegheny and Ohio rivers part flood land.
favor_influences: None from standpoint of home ownership.
detr_influences: Dirt, filth, smoke etc. low type community. One of the toughest sections of Pittsburgh.

notes: Pride of ownership is evident. Not much change in community.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Pittsburgh, No Side
desc_terrain: Fairly level, sloping up from Ohio river.
favor_influences: good transportation, good school
detr_influences: Some industry located in the sections.

notes: Land values are holding section up at present in hope of conversion bus. District of Charles & Strauss Sts. is about 40% colored; about 20% undesirable white population. Some very fine homes still occupied by original owners.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Pittsburgh, No. side
favor_influences: Good transportation, shopping center, within walking distance downtown Stores and offices. Near employment of diversified character.
detr_influences: Old district. No room for residential expansion. Future commercial.

source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Millvale
favor_influences: Has its own shopping center, good transportation, rather an old community. Good school and high school.
detr_influences: Subject to flood in 28 foot stage; sewer backage in buiness section.
relief_fam: Relief load heavy in spots; average for community.

source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Milvale Acres
desc_terrain: Rolling land on top of hill
favor_influences: New development - pleasingly designed building and entire area well kept.
detr_influences: Streets are not paved, but cindered and well kept.

notes: This is a poor man's community generally speaking. No building restrictions. Section is somewhat isolated.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub. Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Fairly new residential area of very modest character.
detr_influences: Large reservior located here. No transportation, Many Unpaved Streets.

source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Etna
desc_terrain: All located in valley and hillsides surrounding the valley.
favor_influences: Good transportation; small town within itself; good railroad facilities; good employment center in good times.
detr_influences: Smoke and dirt from steel mills.

notes: Area is subject to floods, old buildings being torn down. Fast becoming commericial and industrial territory. Generally speaking, properties can be purchased for ground value.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: (Etna) Sharpsberg, Sub-Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Near employment
detr_influences: Subject to floods - Mills, factories, railroads, smoke, dirt, etc.

notes: A small old town in itself; more depreciation and obsolescence apparent year after year. Territory damaged by 1936 flood.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub Pittsburgh - Sharpsburg
favor_influences: Convenient to mills and factories, fair transportation, good schools.
detr_influences: Smoke and dirt from nearby mills, factories, odors from river, subject to high water flood.

notes: This is considered a good working man's district with houses of modest character always in good demand. Section lies out of the flooded area.
source: John J. McKenna, Griffin & Co.
name: Pittsburgh - Morningside
favor_influences: Good transportation, convenient to employment and shopping center
detr_influences: None except age of property

notes: No demand for home purchase since flood. Property near Butler St. between 40th and 47th avenues is considered slightly better than the balance of this section. There is a number of joint home and business properties on  Butler St. Where vacancy is heavy in upstairs units. Many are in vandalized condition. Small industry is sprinkled throughout the area. Mills have moved out of the section and have taken much skilled labor with them.
source: John J. McKenna
name: Pittsburgh - Butler St. Area
favor_influences: Good transportation, near employment of diversified nature.
detr_influences: Old homes in poor condition, subject to floods, smoke and noise from mills.

notes: Considered a good workingman's district. Buildings are old but substantially built. Diversified employment is nearby.
source: J. C. McKenna, Griffin & Co. Property Mgmt. Broker
name: Pittsburgh, Lawrenceville
desc_terrain: Hilly, sloping up from Butler Street.
favor_influences: Near parks. Convenient to employment and commercial areas. Good transportation.
detr_influences: Obsolescence

notes: This is a high class rooming house section with many large houses having been converted to boarding houses. Land values are helping to hold up prices of properties. There are some old apartments with cheap rents which are attracting a less desirable element.
source: Robert Murray
name: Pittsburgh, Liberty Ave. Area
favor_influences: Good transportation. Favorable topography.
detr_influences: Heavy taxes. Large houses difficult to sell.

notes: This is a good 4th grade section. Some Polish people built here about 4 yrs. ago along Kincaid.
source: Ralph George.
name: Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Good transportation in Southern end. Near employment.
detr_influences: Poor class of small houses in poor condition.

notes: A mediocre section at East Liberty.
source: Klemans
name: Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Bounded on North by good section. Near shopping section. Good transportation.
detr_influences: Negro encroachment threatening. Congested area. Obsolescence.

notes: Most of the rental units are duplexes. New building is on subdivided ground of large estates and older houses.
source: Ralph George - H.O.L.C. property-management broker
name: Pittsburgh - Highland Park Section
favor_influences: Near Park. Good general character of people and structures.
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: Considerable development is taking place due north of this section in a development called Wellington Heights, houses there range up to $40,000.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - West View
favor_influences: Good transportation - Public & private schools, local shopping center. Suburban atmosphere
detr_influences: Heavy summer traffic to local amusement park.

notes: In northern portion pride of ownership is exceptionally good. Community spirit prevails. Nice quiet section.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - No Etna
favor_influences: Very fine high school, good bus transportation, suburban atmosphere.
detr_influences: somewhat isolated, smoke from railroad

notes: Commercial section of "Aspinwall" located in this district on First Street.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Lower Aspinwall - Sub Pittsburgh
desc_terrain: Entire area level ground extending back from Allegheny river.
favor_influences: Good transportation, railroad, street car and bus.
detr_influences: Partly flood In March, 1936
inhab_type: Professional and Business & white collared class 40%, Laboring & RR 60%

notes: Newer homes are located in the northern part of this area - price of ownership is evident and properties are generally well maintained.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub. Pittsburgh
desc_terrain: Mostly level - upgrade in North end
favor_influences: Good employment during mill activity good streets.
detr_influences: Some smoke and dirt from nearby mills.
inhab_type: Professional & business & white collar men, 60%; Mill workers & RR Men, 40%

notes: The area is aristocratic. Pride of ownership is very good.  All construction for specific individuals; no operative building.
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Aspinwall - Sub Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Exclusive neighborhood
detr_influences: None except distance to city

notes: Jewish encroachment at southern end from Bryant to Staunton Sts. between Duffield and Heeth St. Better homes are on Morningside avenue between Wellesley and Bryant. Insurance companies are active in this section.
source: J.C.R. Kelly - HOLC
name: Pittsburgh - Morningside
desc_terrain: Level to hilly in Western end
favor_influences: Near Park. Good transportation. A section of modest homes of good character.

notes: Values have been depressed by Jewish encroachment on the following streets: Jancey St. to North St. Clair between Hays and Wellesley. Activity has increased noticeably in past 12 months. This is a fair second grade section.
source: Ralph George
name: Pittsburgh - Highland
desc_terrain: Level to hilly in Eastern end
favor_influences: Good transportation. Near Park. Desirable residential section. Considered good location.
detr_influences: Nominal except somewhat older housing.
build_type: Singles - duplexes - some rows and apartments

notes: Negroes crowded out of D-1 are crowding white men out of the aged and obsolete structures of D-8.
source: J. D. Carneal
name: Richmond, Virginia

notes: Many old houses in fairly good condition. This is a poor third grade area.
source: Robert Murray
name: Pittsburgh, Schenley Hghts.
favor_influences: Fairly desirable residential area. Well located, near park and Cultural center
detr_influences: Obsolescence, steep ascent, very spotty only fair transportation. Overcrowded.

desirability: Downward as residential except on Lytton, Tennyson and Ruskin Streets
notes: Property here is very high grade in good condition ranging in price up to $40,000, and is not to be considered in the same class as the balance of the area.
source: Robert Murray
name: Pittsburgh, Bellefield
desc_terrain: Level to sloping upward to Centre Ave.
favor_influences: Good location. Good transportation. Near Colleges and cultural centers.
detr_influences: Heavy traffic. Proximity to RR and industrial plants.

notes: One of the few level sections in Pittsburgh. A very stable demand exists for property in this section. Large estates are being broken up and smaller units replacing very large houses. Section is graded first grade because of activity and desirability of the area. Older houses at present are difficult to sell except where demolition is feasible and subdividing of ground profitable.
source: Ralph George
name: Pittsburgh - Shadyside
favor_influences: Good transportation. Old but well established and desirable residential section. Near Civic center.
detr_influences: None except many old houses

notes: One of the best sections in the city limits - Houses from $15,000 to $25,000 predominate. Section is threatened with Jewish encroachment from south. Forbes St. frontage is expected to be zoned for apartments.
source: Ralph George
name: Pittsburgh - Squirrel Hill
favor_influences: Highly desirable residential area. Good transportation and shopping center. Good elevation.
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: Slight Jewish encroachment, two new aparts. built off Murray Ave. Considerable commercial Bldg. on Murray Ave. Near Forbs.Very active business center.
source: J.C.R.Kelly-Property review appraiser
name: Pittsburgh - Squirrel Hill
favor_influences: Good transportation - good schools, convenient shopping district, close to parks, good elevation.
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: About 50% of this section is older houses and 50% fairly new. Very little room for expansion or new building except on divided estates.
source: Ralph George
name: Pittsburgh - Homewood
favor_influences: Good transportation. Very good public and private schools. Well restricted. Zoned for best development.
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: A small section of good character well protected from encroachment.
source: J.C.R. Kelley
name: Pittsburgh
desc_terrain: Fairly level on top of hill
favor_influences: Fairly new section well located - near park, good elevation
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: STRONG JEWISH INFLUENCE OF FAIR TO LOWER CLASS JEW.
source: J. C. R. Kelley
name: Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Good transportation - schools - shopping district, near parks
detr_influences: Nominal
inhab_type: White collar class - clerks - some professional men

notes: Strong Catholic influence in this section
source: J.C.R. Kelley
name: Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Near Park and Country Club - good elevation, good transportation, convenient shopping district
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: The section is holding up very well. Considered a desirable residential area for workers in this area. Not attractive to outsiders.
source: H.O. Hornberger - Realtor
name: Pittsburgh - Greenfield
favor_influences: Good transportation, near employment, better class of working men.
detr_influences: Old houses in fair condition.

notes: Few negro in section. Practically a small town within the city.
source: H.O. Hornberger - Realtor
name: Pittsburgh - Hazelwood - Glenwood
desc_terrain: Sloping up the hill from the river
favor_influences: Good transportation. Near employment, practically no foreign. Good business section.
detr_influences: Old houses in fair condition

notes: Property south of Bates avenue is of Better character than those north of this street.
source: Robert Murray, Asst. to St. Mgr. in charge of sales.
name: Pittsburgh - Oakland
favor_influences: Good transportation. Well located section. Near park and colleges.
detr_influences: Smoke from Steel mills along river. Somewhat spotty throughout

notes: Negro concentrated in the northern end of the area. Most of the row houses are held for investment. Values are not expected to increase but to continue their decline still further. Demand for these cheap rental units has been responsible for the entire area.
source: H.O. Hornberger
name: Pittsburgh - Glenwood
desc_terrain: Level, only slightly above river level.
favor_influences: Good transportation. Near employment of diversified nature. Good local business section.
detr_influences: Flood hazard. Obsolescence

notes: Always in demand if local mills operate. Diversified employment nearby.
source: J.C.R. Kelley
name: Sub-Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Near employment
detr_influences: Smoke & soot from mills

notes: Bldg. and loan assns. which normally financed this section are not in position to lend any volume of mortgage money.
source: M. Colbert - Property Mgmt. Div. HOLC
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Ambridge
favor_influences: Near employment.
detr_influences: Very spotty with entire area dependent on local mills which reopened only in early 1936.

source: Colbert
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Ambridge
desc_terrain: Similar in character to the other two sections of Ambridge colored red.
favor_influences: Same as D 31, except some newer homes.

notes: Industry started again in 1936. Building and Loan Assns. had heavy foreclosures throughout. A strictly industrial section attracting only laboring classes. Negro coming in from Leetsdale to get closer to local employment.
source: J.C.R. Kelly
name: Ambridge
favor_influences: Near employment
detr_influences: Houses very close together, concentration of foreign & negro.

notes: Oakmont properties are slightly better than Verona
source: W.S. Klemans
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Oakmont Verona
favor_influences: Near employment which is now active
detr_influences: One principal industry for local support.

notes: Local plants have become active in 1936 after being closed for several years. Old established town again feeling prosperity of mills. Present occupants have been located here for some time.
source: W.S. Klemans
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Oakmont
favor_influences: Suburban atmosphere - desirable residential section. Good transportation to Pittsburgh
detr_influences: Some smoke from local mills.

notes: Entirely dependent on local mills which only recently reopened.
source: W.S. Kleman
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Oakmont, Verona
favor_influences: Near employment - cheap rents
detr_influences: Flood hazard yearly to some degree. Poor housing.

notes: A few very expensive houses are located in this area. A large number of properties are "Company owned".
source: W.A. Stoehr
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Blawnox - Montrose
favor_influences: Good employment during mill activity, good roads.
detr_influences: Smoke & dirt from factories;
inhab_type: White collared & executive 40%, skilled labor & coal Minors 60%

notes: Land values on Penn. Ave. in E. Liberty between Frankstown & Highland Ave. range from $10,000 to $15,000; it is the shopping center for the entire East End District. Chain stores and mail order houses located here. Larimer Ave. is the shopping center for Italian population. Eastern end of this section is best. No market for row houses. Single houses average $1500-5000, about 60% of the owner-occupied homes are mortgaged.
source: Ralph George
name: Pittsburgh, East Liberty
favor_influences: Good transportation, near employment.
detr_influences: Obsolescence. Poor condition of structures, lower class populace.

notes: A section lying in part between two very poor areas. Depreciation is expected to continue very fast because of this influence. About 60% of the owner-occupied homes are mortgaged.
source: J.R. Willison
name: Pittsburgh - Brushton
favor_influences: Nominal
detr_influences: Heavy obsolescence, surrounded by two poorer areas

notes: Many original owners selling on lieberal terms in order to get out of the section.
source: J.R. Willison - Property mgmt. broker
name: Pittsburgh - Brushton
favor_influences: Near employment in E. Liberty district.
detr_influences: Concentration of foreign and negro. Houses in poor condition.

notes: A modest development originally intended for small home owner. Foreclosures were heavy in this section. About 60% of the owner occupied homes are mortgaged. A poor third grade section.
source: Ralph George
name: Pittsburgh - Belmar
favor_influences: Nominal
detr_influences: Only fair transportation. Future of this section is very uncertain. Negro encroachment threatening.

notes: About 50% of the workers are employed in industrial plants and mills along the Manongahela River. The Central part of Wilkinsburg is considered slightly better than the balance of the section.
source: J.R. Willison
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Wilkinsburg
favor_influences: Good transportation, old but well established residential area with good business section.
detr_influences: Obsolescence

notes: Sales market only improved in past 12 months. Marketability somewhat hampered by poor transportation to some corners of this section. Many Westing house employees live here.
source: J.R. Willison
name: Forest Hills - Sub-Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Fairly new development of uniform and modest character. Suburban atmosphere.
detr_influences: Transportation is only fair.

notes: Houses on Maple Avenue range up to 50,000 but the section as a whole is fairly uniform with some moderately large houses. About 60-65% of the owner occupied homes are mortgaged.
source: J.R. Willison
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Edgewood
favor_influences: Good train transportation - high class populace
detr_influences: None except somewhat old

notes: This is only a fair 1st grade section.
source: J.R. Willison
name: Pittsburgh - Regent Square
favor_influences: Homogeneous development of good character. Fairly good transportation. Section overlooks Frick Park.
detr_influences: None except distance to commercial section.

notes: Building prices on new construction has increased about 25% in 12 months of $1200 per unit. Occupants with improved income are anxious to move out. Sales demand is from foreign element in Braddock and Rankin. Local workers dependent on steel mill activity - Shayer Avenue section is the 5th avenue of this area with values ranging up to $15,000. There is a strong church influence in the area.
source: H H. McCulloch
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Swissvale
favor_influences: Near employment. Exceptionally good schools. Fairly desirable residential section.
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: A poor section housing workers with limited incomes.
source: H.H.McCulloch
name: Rankin
desc_terrain: Sloping up from the river - steeply up from Braddock Ave.
favor_influences: Near employment, cheap rents.
detr_influences: Old houses in poor condition, many houses have no bath, smoke & noise from industry.

notes: There is no room for expansion in the city of Braddock with the result there is a tremendous demand for business as the local steel plants are running under 80% of capacity. Values placed on houses by people living in the area are not commensurated with their real worth, but because of the limited ground available prices on present units remain high. The section between N. Holland Ave, 5th St. from Corey to Holland Ave is the best of the section.
source: Hare, Realtor in Braddock
name: (Sub-) Pittsburgh-Braddock
favor_influences: Near employment - very good local shopping center.
detr_influences: Old houses. Overcrowded. Topography.

source: H.H. McCulloch
name: No. Braddock
favor_influences: Similar in character to Swissvale except slightly further out from the center of Pittsburgh

notes: Bessemer Terrace to Ridge Ave. Between Grandview Ave. and Western Ave. has property better than the balance of the section.
source: Hare, Realtor in Braddock
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - E. Pittsburgh
favor_influences: near employment
detr_influences: Old houses in poor condition

notes: Developed by Westinghouse for office employees and shop foremen
source: H. M. McCulbert
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Part of Forest Hill - No. of E. Pitts.
favor_influences: Homogeneous section modest homes - generally desirable
detr_influences: No

notes: Completely dependent on local industry.
source: Colbert
name: Leetsdale
favor_influences: Near employment - Poor transportation to work.
detr_influences: Concentration of foreign and negro in poor housing

notes: Some of Pittsburgh wealthier people own homes in this section.
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Edgeworth
favor_influences: High social Standard - Desirable better class housing. Good train & bus service.
detr_influences: None

notes: Property in this area is very well held; few were placed on the market during the depression. Negro employed as domestics.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Sub-Pittsburgh, Sewickley, Edgeworth
favor_influences: Desirable suburban residential section within commuting distance of Pittsburgh.
detr_influences: Section is somewhat spotty but its general character is good.

notes: Standard Steel Spring Co. strike of 4 months settled early in 1937 has held up recovery which will soon come up to other comparable sections nearby.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Coraopolia
favor_influences: Near employment.
detr_influences: Low ground - poor houses - concentration of foreign and negro

notes: As is typical of small towns, this entire area is very spotty with good and bad properties intermingled. It is not uncommon to find negro houses adjacent to much better units.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Sub-Pittsburgh, Coraopolis
favor_influences: Near local employment - good shopping district. Suburban atmosphere. Local mills operating.
detr_influences: Obsolescence - distance to Pittsburgh

notes: This section is very spotty with negro scattered throughh the best parts. Suburban section to the south, although not shown on map, is very good.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Coraopolis
favor_influences: Suburban atmosphere - near local employment
detr_influences: Neighborhood is very spotty. Distance to Pittsburgh.

notes: Most of the residents work locally.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Sub-Pittsburgh, Carnegie
favor_influences: Desirable section of smaller houses of somewhat recent date. Good transportation. Local employment.
detr_influences: None except topography.

notes: Arch Street section is particularly bad.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Carnegie
desc_terrain: Bottom of valley - sloping up the hillside
favor_influences: Good transportation, local employment, convenient to shopping center.
detr_influences: Section lies poorly, overcrowding of housing.

notes: Section was very bad during the low of the market, but has had definite improvement since 1935. Second generation moving out of the area on Washington, Buckwood and Broadway. Between Ridge and Buckwood for two blocks on each side of Trimble Street are located the best houses in the city ranging in price up to $50,000. Most of the houses are of considerable age, however, with a very limited demand for resale at present these are occupied by local business men and plant executives.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Carnegie
favor_influences: Good transportation, out of noise, near local employment
detr_influences: Obsolesence

notes: Speculators are taking options on properties in hope that Carnegie will buy. There has been some demolition in the section. One of the few level spots in the vicinity.
source: Edw. H. Fahey
name: Sub-Pittsburgh Duquesne
favor_influences: Near employment, values holding up because of possibility of selling to Carnegie Steel Co.
detr_influences: Houses in very poor condition. Smoke and noise from mills

notes: About 15 houses have been built in 1937 to sell for $3500 to $4500; all for specific individuals. This is a heavily congested area as is most of Duquesne.
source: Edward H. Fahey
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Duquesne
desc_terrain: Sloping steeply up the hill from Duquesne Road
favor_influences: Near employment. The best residential section of the city. Considered quite desirable.
detr_influences: Topography - Obsolescence

notes: The only support for the entire Duquesne section is the one Carnegie mill locally.
source: Edw. H. Fahey
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Duquesne
desc_terrain: Sloping steeply up from Duquesne Road
favor_influences: Near employment.
detr_influences: Smoke and dirt from the steel mills. Poor houses in poor condition.

source: Edw. H. Fahey
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Duquesne
desc_terrain: Sloping steeply up from Duguesne Road
favor_influences: Near employment - fairly desirable residential section with some good houses.
detr_influences: Section is quite spotty. Smoke and Dirt from mills.

notes: Part of the section is outside Duquesne city limits.
source: Edw. H. Fahey
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Duquesne
favor_influences: Cheap rent - near employment
detr_influences: Poor location - inaccessible - poor transportation

desirability: Static if improvements are put in.
notes: This section will not bring the prices that Duquesne properties will. Section is enjoying overflow of housing demand from Duquesne.
source: Edw. H. Fahey
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Mifflin Twp. outside Duquesne
favor_influences: More space around houses. Good elevation. Good rental demand.
detr_influences: No paved streets. Sewers partially lacking poor transportation, Heavy taxes, steep ascent from Duquesne.

source: Edw. H. Fahey - Property Mgmt. Broker
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Outside Duquesne
desc_terrain: Level on top of hill back of section C.
favor_influences: Away from smoke from steel mill
detr_influences: Poor property - close to slag dump

notes: A Small section outside Duquesne city limits
source: Edw. H. Fahey
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Outside Duquesne
desc_terrain: Level on hill top overlooking Manogahela River
favor_influences: Near employment - fairly new and desirable residential well removed from smoke from mills.
detr_influences: One industry town

notes: There is considerable changing of occupants in this section. Houses on Duquesne Blvd. near Outlook Ave. are very good.
source: Jas. C. Kuhn
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Homeville
favor_influences: Good elevation, very active section.
detr_influences: Poor transportation

notes: Entire area dependent on mill activity.
source: J. C. Kuhn
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Munhall
favor_influences: Near employment. Good elevation and well planned development.
detr_influences: Poor transportation. Steep ascent to section.

notes: Vacant ground is too hilly for development
source: Jas. C. Kuhn
name: Sub-Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Suburban atmosphere - near employment
detr_influences: Unpaved streets, only fair transportation.

source: J. C. Kuhn
name: Sub-Pittsburgh, Munhall
favor_influences: Suburban atmosphere. Convenient location near employment and shopping district. Good elevation.
detr_influences: Transportation

notes: Streets east of Ellsworth have no sewers.
source: Jas. A. Kuhn
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Munhall
favor_influences: Suburban atmosphere
detr_influences: Some unpaved streets. Only fair transportation. Some cheap construction.

source: Jas. C. Kuhn
name: Sub Pittsburgh - Lincoln Place
favor_influences: Suburban atmosphere
detr_influences: Fair transportation. Isolated section of poor houses.

notes: Housing demand from Homestead has overflowed into this section.
source: Jas. C. Kuhn
name: Sub Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Suburban atmosphere
detr_influences: Poor transportation, isolated section of poor houses.

source: J. C. Kuhn - Property Mgmt.t Broker
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Homestead
favor_influences: Near employment. Good class of people.
detr_influences: Obsolescence

notes: This is a good 4th grade section. Entire area depends on mill activity.
source: J. C. Kuhn
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Homestead
favor_influences: Good elevation, near employment
detr_influences: Obsolescence. Poor class of populace

notes: Many mill superintendents and better paid office employees live here.
source: J. C. Kuhn
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Homestead
favor_influences: Near employment, near park and library. Good class of populace.
detr_influences: Obsolescence

notes: Many houses have two and three families living in two or three rooms. Rents were not collectable when mills were shut down. Considerable demolition 1933-35 to save taxes. Good possibility of ground between river and RR being purchased by industry. Property south of 8th Avenue is slightly better.
source: J. C. Kuhn
name: Sub Pittsburgh - Homestead
desc_terrain: Level - sloping slightly up from the river
favor_influences: Near employment - convenient to shopping district on 8th Ave.
detr_influences: Smoke from steel mills. Houses are overcrowded, mixture of population.

notes: Valley section marked Hays is very crowded
source: J. C. Kuhn
name: Sub Pittsburgh - New Homestead
favor_influences: Good elevation overlooking river, near employment suburban atmosphere.
detr_influences: Section is very spotty, cheap construction, no sewers or paving in some parts.

notes: Activity only started in past 15 months. Principally F.H.A financing on new construction.
source: Gerald A. Born, Property Management Broker
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Brentwood
favor_influences: Fairly new desirable residential area with suburban atmosphere. Good bus service.
detr_influences: None except distance to commercial area

notes: 30 units built in 1937 to sell from $7,000-10,000. A fairly good section usable for expansion from Knoxville, Carrick & Mt. Oliver.
source: Gerald A. Born
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Brentwood
desc_terrain: Rolling - slopes down from Brownesville Road which is the crest of the hill.
favor_influences: Good bus transportation - rather desirable residential section.
detr_influences: None except very hilly

notes: Knoxville is a very stable neighborhood - houses are better than most of the rest of the section but the entire area is very spotty. Many houses need paint and minor repairs. About 55% of the owner occupied homes are mortgaged.
source: Gerald A. Born
name: Pittsburgh - Carrick, Knoxville
desc_terrain: Hilly, sloping both sides from Brownesville road
favor_influences: Good transportation, shopping districts
detr_influences: Topography, densely populated
inhab_type: White collar class - clerks - small business men

notes: The least developed section which is close to the commercial area of Pittsburgh.
source: W.S. Klemans
name: Pittsburgh- Overbrook
favor_influences: Surrounding territory is good and new development appears to be better in this section.
detr_influences: None except topography, some question of undermining

notes: Dormont has a very good business section, a post office branch and two branch banks. Brookline also has a branch bank and a shopping center on Brookline Blvd. Greatest danger of mine cave is in lower lying section.
source: J. C. Gilson - Property Mgmt. Broker - Freehold Realty Co.
name: Pittsburgh, Dormont Brookline
favor_influences: Good transportation, bus trolley - Desirable residential area. Restricted development.
detr_influences: Much of the territory is undermined and some houses have sagged slightly.

notes: Strong Catholic influence in this area. Advance in rentals must be predicted on reconditioning.
source: J.C. Gilson - Freehold Realty
name: Pittsburgh - Beechview
desc_terrain: Hilly, sloping up from W. Liberty Road.
favor_influences: Direct transportation through tubes to Pittsburgh business district.
detr_influences: Houses on small lots not well planned

notes: Mortgage funds are available at 40-50% of appraisal. A good portion of these properties are built on the hillside and valley bottoms. Negro concentrated in St. Clair. Section is very spotty throughout. Many houses need paint and minor repairs.
source: Gerald A. Born
name: Pittsburgh - St. Clair - Knoxville
desc_terrain: Hilly - sloping down from Brownesville Road, section
favor_influences: Nominal
detr_influences: Many unpaved streets. Topography is not readily appreciable to residential building. Section is very spotty with much cheap construction of considerable age.

notes: A very spotty section with some fair property on some streets. Some demolition for reducing taxes. Most of this section lies at the foot of the hill along the Monogahela river. About 45% of the owner-occupied homes are mortgaged. All alleys built with rows. 17th to 22nd on Sarah, Jane, & Mary are good class Polish. German settlement on St. Pauls off South 18th St.
source: Gerald A. Born
name: Pittsburgh - Carson St. Section
desc_terrain: Level to hilly - sloping up from river.
favor_influences: Close to employment, cheap rents.
detr_influences: Very poor neighborhood - smoke and soot from mills - flood area.

notes: Thrifty class of people in this locality many old German families. Houses in the Buell foundation section are definitely better than the rest of the section; Oneida St. south of Virginia.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Duquesne Heights
favor_influences: Good transportation, near employment, good elevation
detr_influences: Heavy obsolescence, houses too close together

notes: Recent letting of contract to pave Banksville Road will add another outlet for heavy traffic into this area. The foreclosures were very heavy throughout Mt. Lebanon. About 80 % of the homes were mortgaged in 1934.
source: J.C.Gibson
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Mt. Lebanon
favor_influences: Homogeneous development of good character. Good transportation. Very desirable residential section.
detr_influences: Some danger of mine cave causing houses to sag, particularly on the hill sides.

notes: Coal operations have stayed development of this section.
source: W.S. Klemons - Property Appraiser, HOLC Pittsburgh
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Castle Shannon
favor_influences: Fairly new residential area surrounded by good sections. Good Transportation.
detr_influences: Dust from Coal mine. Undermining of ground. No sewers on Southern hills edge

notes: Considerable Jewish throughout the 5th Ave. Section. Demolition for tax purposes and poor condition. Values of residential structures is expected to continue down. Rentals have about reached a peak now. Northeast corner is the best of the entire section: North of Webster and East of Morgan. The poorest area in the territory bounded by 5th Ave., Congress St., Bedford & Erin St. has been mentioned for slum clearance.
source: W.S. Klemans
name: Pittsburgh, Hill Dist.
favor_influences: Near center of town - near Civic center Park
detr_influences: Concentration of negro and undesirables, very congested.

notes: A rather old section but it is well established. About 55% of the owner-occupied homes are mortgaged. A fair second grade section. Hastings Avenue as far south as Rockshale Road has poorer housing in only fair condition.
source: Ralph George
name: Pittsburgh
favor_influences: Good transportation. Very convenient location. Good class of populace.
detr_influences: Age of many properties. Possibility of apartment house encroachment.

notes: Older houses not finding a ready market, but new homes are being built for specific individuals. Only about 200 houses in this section. Section east of Park Road is not up to the standard of the balance of Rosslyn Farms area.
source: R.K. Meselbarth
name: Sub-Pittsburgh - Rosslyn Farms, Thornburg
favor_influences: Considered a desirable residential section. A wooded section of good character. Good populace.
detr_influences: Poor transportation - isolated.

notes: Crafton has larger ground units and the section enjoys a good name, although part of the area is spotty. Many original owners still in the section, but younger generation is not       locally.  Properties on hill tops are generally considered more desirable than than those on hillside.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Pittsburgh, Crafton, Ingram, and Sheraden
desc_terrain: Hilly, rolling down from hill top
favor_influences: Good transportation - desirable residential section
detr_influences: Nominal except somewhat spotty

notes: Lorenz Ave. to Chartier Ave. are business. Strahle Place houses are good and fairly new ranging in price up to $9000. Ordinary section of modest homes.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Pittsburgh, Eilliott, Part of Sheraden
favor_influences: Good transportation, near employment areas.
detr_influences: Obsolescence setting in in parts of the area, slowly going foreign.

notes: Little demand for housing since the 1936 flood - values are not expected to improve from the present low level. Rents have increased as rapidly as other section because of uncertainty of receivership of Pressed Steel Car Co.
source: T.K. Heselbarth - Property Mgmt. Broker
name: McKees Rocks
favor_influences: Near employment of well diversified character.
detr_influences: Subject to flood - poor housing

notes: Outside city limits of McKees Rocks. Good demand for units from workers locally. RR shops, many industries located nearby.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: McKees Rocks
desc_terrain: Hilly, in a valley between hills
favor_influences: Near employment, fairly desirable residential area for better paid local workers.
detr_influences: Mixture of older houses in fair condition

notes: Demolition in the section. Developing into light manufacturing. Main St. is commerical. Many slum houses held for income purposes. Other houses are not expected to increase over present valuations. most of the dwelling units are overcrowded.
source: T.K. Heselbarth
name: Pittsburgh - West End.
desc_terrain: Lies in bottom of valley - sloping up from river.
favor_influences: Good transportation, near employment.
detr_influences: Old property in poor condition, concentration of negro & foreigners.

notes: This is the newest development in the city. Sales prices increased only in early 1937. The foreign which has bought into this area is of very high class and not undesirable to other residents.
name: New Castle, Penn
favor_influences: Homogeneous development of high class homes. Wooded section of newer homes attracting younger local business. Good transportation.
detr_influences: Nominal.

notes: Considered a good residential area. Commercial area centered at Norwood and Highland Avenue. Before the development of A-1 and A-2 this section was the best residential section of New Castle.
name: New Castle, Penn.
desc_terrain: Rolling to level at Northern end.
favor_influences: Good transportation- schools-churches. Desirable residential of homogeneous development.
detr_influences: nominal

notes: Previous to developments of section A-1 this area was the very best residential section in the city. It is still very desirable with high class populace residing in original homes. As is typical of smaller towns, some streets are a little spotty, but the reputation of the section is good.
name: New Castle, Penn.
desc_terrain: Slightly rolling toward center of city.
favor_influences: Restricted development of high class homes. Good Transportation
detr_influences: Nominal other than somewhat spotty

notes: Growth is anticipated because of general desirability of the area. The section is a modest development of smaller homes of good character.
name: New Castle, Penn
favor_influences: Fairly new desirable section with good transportation. Convenient to center of city.
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: Commercial area centered at Wellington and Edison Avenues
name: New Castle, penn
favor_influences: Good transportation- schools, churches. Desirable residential area of modest homes
detr_influences: Age of property

notes: Many original owners still living in the section. Some large houses are being converted into apartments. Section is slowly going into business and is in direct line of growth; expansion however, will be very slow. Originally the best section of New Castle.
name: New Castle, Penn.
desc_terrain: Sloping slightly toward center of city.
favor_influences: Central location.
detr_influences: Obsolescence- small business encroachment.

notes: A boarding & rooming house section of only fair character.
name: New Castle, Penn
desc_terrain: Level- steeply up the hill in Western end.
favor_influences: Central location- near employment.
detr_influences: Obsolescence- shifting populations- poor elevation.

name: New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: Good transportation- schools- churches.
detr_influences: Foreign settlement of medium class.

notes: A large cement plant which formerly furnished employment to workers is this section closed down during the depression and its reopening is questionable. There are few paved streets in this area
name: New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: None except free from industrial dirt.
detr_influences: Removal of local employment- poor houses- Distance to center of city

notes: Housing here is in fair demand because the section is fairly clean and away from the industrial plants along the river.
name: New Castle, Penn.
desc_terrain: Level close to center of city. Sloping in eastern end.
favor_influences: Near employment- central location.
detr_influences: Nominal- obsolescence.

notes: Commercial section along South Mill St. and at Pearson & Taylor. Shopping center on Long St.
name: New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: Good tranportation. Several parks in the area.
detr_influences: Obsolescence.

notes: Foreign from this section trying to move into B-4. The area in return is attracting residents from section C-5.
name: New Castle, Penn
favor_influences: Good transportation- schools- churches
detr_influences: Some unpaved streets- heavy foreign population.

notes: Section is attracting better class of foreigners from south side. Washington Street has small business throughout its entire length.
name: New Castle, Penn
favor_influences: Good transportation- schools- churches. Desirable section of modest homes.
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: Negro and white intermingled in poor housing which is in demand when local mills are operating as they now are.
name: New CAstle, Penn.
favor_influences: Near employment and local shopping center. Large hospital keeps hospital attendants locally.
detr_influences: Smoke & noise from mills- class of population.

notes: Section is known as Goat Hill. Considered a very stable neighborhood with good type Polish inhabitants.
name: New Castle & So. New Castle Penn.
favor_influences: Near employment along river. Four shopping center. Has own Polish schools and churches.
detr_influences: No sewers outside city limits. Smoke & soot from mills

notes: Very poor section located between two industrial plants which make the area very dirty. Many shack type houses scattered throughout and the section is desirable primarily because it is near employment.
name: New Castle
favor_influences: Near employment- cheap rents
detr_influences: Smoke, dirt and noise from mills. Low class populace. Poor houses.

notes: Greatest value is for conversion to business purposes. Commercial growth of the city is in opposite direction. This section is similar in character to D-3 but not as well located for business expansion. Rentals were not collected during depression and vacancy was the heaviest in the city.
name: New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: Central location- near employment
detr_influences: Dirt and noise from mills. Obsolescence. Housing in poor condition. Low class populace.

rentdemand2: Many apts. not fit for use.
notes: Greatest value of property is for conversion to business but growth of the commercial area is in the opposite direction. There is a good percentage of apartments above business properties. Rentals during depression were difficult to collect and vandalism was prevalent.
name: New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: Central location- near employment.
detr_influences: Noise from business houses- obsolescence

notes: A very poor negro section known locally as Snake's Rest.
name: New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: Near employment- good transportation.
detr_influences: Concentration of negro in poor housing. Many houses are too low for sewer line.
inhab_type: Labor- low class white and negro

notes: A poor section of lower class inhabitants living in crowded quarters.
name: New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: Near employment- cheap rents.
detr_influences: Undesirable section. Near garbage plant.

notes: Commercial section along Wasington St.
name: New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: Good elevation- good transportation. Somewhat isolated from dirt from industrial plants.
detr_influences: No city sewers in some parts

notes: This location is very good and activity is expected to continue. Many lots have been sold recently. Development will probably be of modest homes on fairly good sized lots. Financing is available on somewhat limited terms.
name: Sub. New Castle, Penn.
favor_influences: Low taxes- good schools. Quiet residential section of good character.
detr_influences: No sewers.

notes: Principally a mill section depending on industrial activity of mille.
name: Mahooing, Sub. New Castle, Penn
desc_terrain: Level to hilly in northern end.
favor_influences: Near employment.
detr_influences: Smoke & soot from mills.

notes: Through trains of P. & L.E. R.R., & O. and Pe. R.R. run through this town making bus contact with New Castle. This is the best residential part of Mahoning.
name: Mahoning, Penn (Sub. New Castle Level.
favor_influences: Two good streets of desirable prperties near R.R. employment.
detr_influences: Smoke and noise from mills & R.R. yards

notes: Similar in general character to Section D-7.
name: Mahoning- Sub. New Castle Penn.
favor_influences: Near employment.
detr_influences: Smoke, dirt and noise from mills. Low class populace. Poor houses

notes: An industrial laborers section of poor housing in good demand primarily because of location and cheap rentals.
name: Mahoning- Sub. New Castle Penn.
favor_influences: Near employment
detr_influences: Smoke, noise and dirt from mills. Subject to flood in part.

notes: Highly desirable location. Restricted. Practically all new properties, shrubbery and landscaping. Pride of ownership.
source: George E. Layers
name: Lorain
favor_influences: Adjoins beach, surrounds public park, good transportation. Best bathing beach along Lake Erie.

notes: Highly desirable location. Restricted. Practically all new properties, shrubbery and landscaping. Pride of ownership.
source: George E. Meyers
name: Lorain
favor_influences: Adjoins beach, surrounds public park, good transportation. Best bathing beach along Lake Erie.

notes: Few nice homes in northern part. Newer homes in southern part of area.
source: Geo. E. Meyers

favor_influences: Good transportation; near school.

notes: Few nice homes in northern part. Newer homes in southern part of area.
