favor_influences: Good transportation- not far from beach.
detr_influences: Adjoins Railroad on North.

notes: Lots in extreme eastern section from Iowa to Louisiana Avenues were formerly owned by U.S. Government. Practically all new homes are located in this section.
source: F.E. Babcock
name: Lorain
favor_influences: Good transportation. Near School,
detr_influences: Near ship yards on west end. Noise, dirt and some smoke.

notes: Lots in extreme eastern section from Iowa to Louisiana Avenues were formerly owned by U.S. Government. Practically all new homes are located in this section.
source: F.E. Babcock
name: Lorain
favor_influences: Good transportation. Near school.
detr_influences: Near ship yards on west end. Noise, dirt and some smoke.

notes: Desirable location. Platted just before depression set in. Now coming back slowly.
source: George E. Meyers
name: Lorain
favor_influences: Close to lake front.
detr_influences: Nominal

notes: Desirable location. Platted just before depression set in. Now coming back slowly.
source: George E. Meyers
name: Lorain
favor_influences: Close to lake front.
detr_influences: nominal

notes: The section south of street car line is a newer allotment. Three fine homes under construction. Boulevard system streets. Highly desirable. Few old homes interspersed keep this area from being classified green.
source: M.F. Peer
name: Lorain
favor_influences: Highly restricted; new development; best residential area. Adjoins fine bathing beach.
detr_influences: Main highway trasverses through area.

notes: The section south of street car line is a newer allotment. Three fine homes under construction. Boulevard system streets. Highly desirable. Few old homes interspersed keep this area from being classfied green.
source: M.F. Peer
name: Lorain
favor_influences: Highly restricted; new development; best residential area. Adjoins fine bathing beach.
detr_influences: Main highway traerses trough area.

notes: Comparatively new addition.
source: F.E. Babcock
name: Lorain

notes: Comparatively new addition.
source: F.E. Babcock
name: Lorain

notes: Population decreasing because of demolition to save taxes.
source: J. D. Carneal
name: Richmond, Virginia
relief_fam: High in relation to the whole

notes: Tuckaseegee Road running through section connects with one of main highways leading from Charlotte and quite a few filling stations have recently been erected on this road.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, communtiy business center.
detr_influences: Lack of adequate transportation.  Distance to schools.  Distance from main business district.

notes: There are only a few private owned properties in this section.  About 1931, by reason of mill going broke, these mill houses were open to rent to anyone.  At this time another factory has been opened and the houses are only available for factory employees.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: School, churches, near adequate transportation and near community business center.
detr_influences: Box factory in this area and most of properties are company owned.

notes: The section along Roslyn Ave. & Rozzells Ferry Road has developed since 1926 and contains some nice small singles.  The section east of Rozzels Ferry Road is one of the older sections of the city, with properties medium priced and fairly well maintained.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, paved streets, good transportation faciltiies, school and churches located in district.  Also community business center located in the area.
detr_influences: Negro university adjoining section - also box factory.  Adjoining section on north is negro section.

notes: On the eastern side of this section is quite a large area devoted to warehouses and commercial establishments, facing on W. Morehead Ave.  It is anticipated that this development will expand Westward on Morehead and lots on the southern side of the area are being held by the developer for sale for commercial purposes.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Community business center, adequate transportation, close proximity to schools and churches.
detr_influences: Steady encroachment of commercial and industrial development along W. Morehead with vacant lots on the south side of this section facing W. Morehead, being retained by developer for sale for commercial establishments.
build_type: Small singles & some duplexes & 4 family apartments

notes: This area is a cotton mill village - most all of the population working in the mill and most all properties owned by the mill.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Close to Park
detr_influences: At edge of city limits, inadequate transportation, lack of schools and churches, cotton mill community with mill located in area, majority of houses being company owned.

notes: Most highly desirable like, A-5, but less costly homes are permitted under the restrictions than in A-5
name: Richmond, Virginia
desc_terrain: On a wooded steep bluff overlooking sweeping curve in the river. Awe-inspiring view.

notes: The western part of area is composed of better class negro properties and eastern part of the area is composed of low-type negro rental properties.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Western side adjoins negro college, adequate transportation facilities, near white community business center, close to schools and churches.
detr_influences: Cemetery adjoining part of area, old type construction, negro population, creek runs through part of area.
build_type: Small cottages and some large singles

notes: As a whole this section is a "High" yellow.  It is one of the older sections with some very nice properties on the north side of Trade St.
source: Mr. C. W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Elementary & High School, churches, business center, good transportation facilities.  Older residential section well kept.
detr_influences: Creek running through area, adjoining cemetery and negro section. Close proximity to main business district.
build_type: Large & Small Singles, some 4 family apts.

notes: Major portion of properties in this area all cheap grade of negro houses built for rental purposes.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation, schools, churches, negro hospital
detr_influences: Type of population, cheap construction

notes: The western part of the area is known as "Biddleville" and along Oaklawn Ave. and W. Trade St. are many better grade negro properties occupied by negro professors teaching in the negro college, negro brick masons, and other skilled negro mechanics, but interspersed with these better grade properties are many lower grade properties.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Schools and churches located in area, also community business district.  Negro College adjoining area on south.
detr_influences: Inadequate transportation for center of area.  Cotton Oil Mill located in eastern part of area.
inhab_type: Negro skilled mechanics, laborers, domestics, negro teachers

notes: This area has only a small number of houses in it but they are of better type than the adjoining.  There is one large country home located in the area.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Nothing particular
detr_influences: No transportation facilties, lack of close proximity to schools, churches, business centers.

notes: This is one of the older sections of the city, with growing tendency to boarding and rooming houses.  Houses are old & obsolete.  There are several large apartments and also several smaller ones.  Close proximity to business district makes good rental demand.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Close to main business district, schools, & churches.  Adequate transportation facilities.
detr_influences: Age of properties - type of construction
build_type: Large two story singles, many apartments

notes: Area composed of negroes and low-income white people.  The northern part of the area along Hutchison Ave. has very little development.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation, close to schools and churches.
detr_influences: Railroad shops, negro section, obsolete properties, oil storage tanks, warehouses located in the area.

notes: The southern part of this area is "High" yellow.  In the northern part of the area, along Hutchison Ave., there is a tendency towards industrial development and several plants are now located here.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Southern part has bus transportation and elementary school also located in this part.
detr_influences: Adjacent to industrial area.  Railroad adjoins northern part on Eastern side, and property along the tracks has tendency toward industrial development.

notes: The great majority of houses in this area all small cheap negro houses, and others are large-type single houses used as boarding and rooming houses in that part of the area adjoining main business district.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Has all city conveniences, close to schools and churches and main business district.
detr_influences: Old community, cheap construction, type of population.
build_type: Large old type singles and small cottages

notes: In portion of area between Charles Ave. & 22nd St. majority of houses owned by cotton mill and rented to operatives.  Northern part of area is the better part, containing larger percentage of home ownership, and can be classed as "High" red.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Schools and churches, community business center, fair transportation facilities.
detr_influences: Encroachment of industrial development, cotton mills in area, railroad on west side and adjoining it is Swift Refining Co. and many other warehouses and industrial plants.

notes: The section lying north of the railroad is the most desirable portion.  Homes are built on lots larger than average size.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: No particular favorable influences.
detr_influences: Lack of adequate transportation, lack of close proximity to schools and churches.  Railroad running through area.

notes: The northeast portion of this area, lying east of Plaza, is a subdivision which has been developed within past ten years, and rates a "High" yellow.  That portion lying southeast of Plaza and adjoining Area B-1 is also a "High" yellow benefitting from close proximity to Area B-1.  That part west of Plaza and north of Parkway contains the older properties in this section and rates a "low" yellow.
source: Mr. C. W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation for that part located within city limits.  Small community business center located at corner of Plaza and Lola Ave.
detr_influences: Majority of streets unpaved - schools, churches not easily accessible.

desirability: On west side static, on east side static to upward
notes: The western side of the section is about 15 years old and when first started it gave evidence of an "A" grade; however, construction of some cheaper houses tended to halt its advance.  On the eastern side there has been quite a large amount of new construction during the past 18 months.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Construction fairly modern & uniform.  Area close to Country Club.  Transportation facilities adequate on western side of area but not so good on eastern side adjoining area A-1 but on this side development is more recent, of good uniform construction.
detr_influences: No schools, churches, or community business center in the area.

notes: In 1929 there were only about six residences in this section, the majority of which were large estates.  Type of construction and price range would indicate that lack of adequate transportation facilities would not be detrimental.  Area is being slowly developed - with a tendency from the "Estate Class" to the $12,500 to the $25,000 range.
source: Mr. C. W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative, and Personal Inspection.
name: Charlotte
favor_influences: Adjoins Charlotte Country Club
detr_influences: Major portion outside city limits - no transportation facilities.
rent1929: Nothing ever rented in this area

notes: The northern part of the area is a "High" yellow while that part along Central Avenue is a "low" yellow.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C
favor_influences: Has all city conveniences.  Properties adjoining B-1 are of fairly good construction.  Elementary school located on Central Avenue.
detr_influences: Lack of adequate transportation, property fronting on Central Avenue is low, several small type filling stations and grocery stores combined located on Central Avenue.  Properties are of cheap type of construction on Central Avenue.

notes: The area consists largely of medium priced single family homes.  Occupied by people of medium income who take pride in home ownership.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation facilities, adjoins private golf course.  Community business center located on Central Ave. about 4 blocks from this area.
detr_influences: Schools not very convenient.  Coal yard and manufacturing plant located on railroad only about 2 blocks from this area.

notes: This entire area can be termed a "High" yellow, the railroad running through it and the location in the area of the coal yard and factory keeping it from being a "B" area.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Higher type areas on two sides - close proximity to adequate transportation - all city conveniences.
detr_influences: Railroad running through area.  Coal yard and industrial plant located on railroad.

notes: On Elizabeth Avenue there are several very nice old type large residences which are gradually being converted into boarding and rooming houses; also, several apartment houses with apartments renting around $40.00.  The area adjoining Independence Park and B-3 might be termed "High" yellow.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Senior High School, Elementary School located in the area; also, community business center.  Adjoining Independence Park - all city conveniences - adequate transportation facilities.
detr_influences: Adjoining business district, negro sections on two sides, old type of construction.  Boarding and rooming houses - some apartments.

notes: Area contains a mixture of population type.  Properties are not uniform, containing many small homes and also quite a few larger old type houses.  That part of area adjoining B-1 is a "High" yellow.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Transportation facilitates adequate, churches & schools located in the area, community business center.
detr_influences: Railroad tracks running through southwest corner of area.  Cotton mill is located in the area.  Majority of properties in excess of 20 years of age.
inhab_type: Clerical, mechanics, factory workers and laborers.

notes: This area is composed of better grade of negro properties, occupied largely by domestics who earn their livlihood in the better areas adjoining.  It is not considered as having a detrimental influence on the adjoining areas.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adjoining high type area, close to schools and churches and community business center.
detr_influences: Entirely negro population.

name: Richmond, Virginia
detr_influences: Dozen or less homes, very old - No activity

notes: The northern portion of this area consists of older properties while the southern portion contains properties of more recent construction.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Churches, elementary, Junior High & Senior High Schools, park, community business center all located in and adjoining this area.  Good transportation facilities.
detr_influences: Nothing particular
build_type: Large & Small singles & some 4 family apartments

notes: One of the older negro sections of the city - adjoining main business district.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation, schools, churches.
detr_influences: Cheap properties, negro section almost entirely, and old community.
build_type: Few large singles and small cottages

notes: On Morehead Ave. there is located several large expensive homes occupied by fairly wealthy people.  On Royal Court are several 4 family apartments.  The area to the north is occupied by negroes but there is hardly any possibility of an encroachment into this area, B6.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative, and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation, close proximity to schools, churches and community business center.  Substantial type of citizenship.
detr_influences: Close proximity to negro area - practically 100% developed.
build_type: Large singles on Morehead - 4 family apts. and small singles on Royal Court & Kent

notes: The northern and eastern sides of this area adjoin vacant plots extending down Sugar Creek and on which there is very little likelihood of future development.  The adjoining area (D-3) on the North is predominately negro and cheap construction; however, there is little probability of any expansion of this D-3 area that will encroach on B-4.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative, and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation facilities, community business center.  Close proximity to schools and churches.
detr_influences: Nothing Particular

notes: The Southern part of this area has long been one of the most desirable residential areas in Charlotte, and land occupancy in this part is approximately 85%.  The northern part of the area around Latta Park is gradually being developed with good, large, substantial single family residences of uniform and modern construction.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative, and Personal Inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Area has excellent transportation facilities, close to elementary & Junior High School, contains churches and community business center.  All vacant lots in that section (around Latta Park) are owned by one person who has heretofor held prices up.
detr_influences: Adjoining area on North (D-3) is a negro section of very cheap properties; however, it is hardly likely that Area D-3 will ever expand further southward into Area A-3.

notes: E. Boulevard is one of older better-class residential streets with many large old-type substantial residences, many of which are still occupied by people of substantial means.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation, adjoining Latta Park, schools and churches in area.  Also community business center and Post Office Sub-station.
detr_influences: Nothing particular
inhab_type: Executives, business men, clerical, skilled mechanics

notes: The center of the area, Kingston Ave. and Park Ave., contains a fairly good substantial type of small singles, fairly uniform and can be termed "High" yellow.  The eastern side of the area is also a "High" yellow.  The part west of Mint St. might be termed "low" yellow.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: Schools, churches in area, adequate transportation facilities, community business center.
detr_influences: City dump and incinerator near southwest corner this area.  Some industrial plants and commercial companies located on Mint St.

notes: The portion of the area along Sherman Avenue contains a better grade of negro properties but lack of city conveniences has a tendency to keep trend of desirability downward.
source: Mr. C.W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative and personal inspection.
name: Charlotte, N.C.
favor_influences: None
detr_influences: Inadequate transportation - at edge of city limits.  City Incinerator and Charlotte Slaughter House located in the area.  Lack of schools, churches, business community centers.  No sewer, lights, or gas.

notes: On the western side of this area is that part just north of Gaston St. indicated as undeveloped are located 6 houses occupied by negroes. However, there is very little if any likelihood of any increase in negro population in this area. Future development will eventually drive the negroes out. New construction is in the Westerwood subdivision in the northern part of the area. Properties adjoining industrial and commercial development along railroad track is somewhat adversly affected by this condition.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All conveniences, close to main business district, adjoining two girls' colleges, adequate transportation, good surroundings.
detr_influences: Railroad running through eastern part of area with some industrial plants and warehouses located along the tracks.

notes: Area D-4 adjoining on the northwest is a negro section a great many of whom are domestics earning livelihood in Area A-2.  The population of area D-4 is not increasing and there is no infiltration of negroes into Area A2.  The porperties in the northwestern portion of Area A-2 are the older properties in this area, but the predominating are large, substantial homes.
source: Mr. C. W. Nixon, Loan Service Field Representative, and Personal Inspection
name: Charlotte
favor_influences: Predominating construction is modern and uniform.  Area has all city conveniences, adjoins Myers Park Golf Club, contains Queens Chicora College, has adequate transportation facilities, contains elementary school, churches representing 3 denominations; also contains community business center.  Area is strongly restricted.
detr_influences: None

notes: That part of the area on the east adjoining main business section contains some large single family dwellings, well maintained, and occupied as homes by a high type of citizenship, but properties are old and as owners are able to sell at reasonable prices they are moving to better areas. The western side of the area contains many cheap cottages. That part of the area along Wendover St. is fair and a little better type of construction than the western part.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation
detr_influences: Quite a few commercial establishments along Battle Ground Avenue- cemetery, power plant, city water works plant, railroad and industrial plants along track. The eastern side of area is adjacent to main business district; contains older properties.

notes: The central part of the section around Elm St. is the most desirable part of this area. The eastern side being along the main line of the Southern Railroad has some sales resistance from this fact and the western side has sales resistance on account of being adjacent to cemetery. However, because of its nearness to the business district and other conveniences, it is still a desirable section in which to live.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, close to park, schools, churches, community business center located in the area.
detr_influences: Railroad on the east, cemetery on the west. Elm St. is zoned for business to a point 200 ft. north of West Fisher.

notes: This is one of the older sections of Greensboro but it is still one of the most desirable residential sections. In the center of the section is "Fisher Park", and this is a feature that adds to the desirability of the section. There is a gradual encroachment of apartment houses and duplexes, and it will not be many years before there will be a transition nito a "B" area- all depending on the growth of Greensboro and general conditions.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H. O. L. C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Schools, park, churches, close to community business center, also fairly close to main business district. Transportation facilities good.
detr_influences: Slight encroachment of apartment houses.
inhab_type: Executives, business men, and professional men

notes: Chief desirable feature of this area is the fact that it is the main artery leading from sections A-1 to A-2. There are only about a dozen dwellings in the area. It is also close to main business district. Future development will probably not lower the desirability of the section, and there is a probability that its desirability will be increased.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation facilities, all city conveniences, the main approach to Irving Park.
detr_influences: Large warehouse located one block to the west. Heavy traffic on Elm St.

notes: Very old section of Greensboro. Vacant area on the north is owned by the mill people.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation, close to schools and community business center.
detr_influences: Adjoining negro section, properties old, railroad track on western side, athletic stadium on eastern side.

notes: This is one of the older sections of Greensboro. Its desirability is enhanced by the location in the area of one of the best schools in the city.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales & Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Schools in area, close to churches, close to community business, adequate transportation, all city conveniences.
detr_influences: Nothing special. Surrounded by lower type of property and vacant area on north owned by Cone Interests, who own the cotton mills further to the north.

notes: This is one of the best negro residential sections in the city, the reason for this being its close proximity to the negro A. & T. State College.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, close to colored college, adequate transportation.
detr_influences: Surrounded by a very cheap type of negro property.
inhab_type: Negro college teachers, good negro domestics, negro practical

notes: This is a typical southern negro section composed mostly of laborers and domestics of all types.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Adjoining A & T negro College, also negro Lutheran College, has all city conveniences, adequate transportation along Market St.
detr_influences: Railroad track through south central, major portion without adequate transportation.

notes: This is another good residential negro section, close proximity to colored college being a contributing factor. Negro swimming pool now being constructed on Benbow Rd. Good negro hospital also adds to section.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adjoining colored college, colored hospital in area.
detr_influences: Transporation only fair, surrounded by cheaper type of negro property.
inhab_type: Negro college teachers, good negro domestics, mechanics

notes: This section largely consisting of cheap type of negro cottages.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Northwest part adjoins Bennett College for colored, city conveniences.
detr_influences: Somewhat isolated, transportation not very good.

notes: The northeast corner adjacent to negro college is populated by negroes. The southwest corner contains what is known as "Arlington Park" is a recently developed subdivision of the past 5 to 7 years. This subdivision contains small singles. The northwest corner adjoins business section and contains some cheaper apartments and duplexes. The southeast section is the direction in which the area will expand. Asheboro, formerly one of the good streets in Greensboro, and there are quite a few nice homes on it.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales & Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation, schools located in area, churches, community business center.
detr_influences: On the wrong side of the city. Negro residential sections adjoins on two sides, older type of houses predominate. Fertilizer plants on south out Randolph Avenue.
build_type: Small singles, some large singles, few duplexes

notes: The northern part of this section including area around Chas. D. McIver school is populated by white people, but close proximity to negro population and industrial district along the railroad track has a tendency to decrease desirability.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales & Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation, close to main business district, schools (both colored and white), all city conveniences.
detr_influences: Railroad through northern part, industrial plant along railroad track, obsolete houses.

notes: This is one of the old sections, adjoining main business district. It contains many large, old-type homes which are gradually being converted into rooming and boarding houses.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation, close to main business district.
detr_influences: Old properties, houses going into cheaper boarding and rooming houses, business section encroaching

notes: Northeast corner of this area along Rankin & Carr, and along Spring Garden is the better part of the area. West of Hicks Court on McGee St. there are approximately 14 negro houses but no likelihood of further encroachment. Along Spring Garden are some large, older homes. Vick Chemical Co. plant located to the east of Engelwood and west of Chapman. Negro population also on Patterson, Harman, and Watts St. in that part directly to the south of the railroad yards.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales & Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation to part north of railroad and out Glenwood Avenue, community business district, schools and churches.
detr_influences: Industrial area along railroad trakcs, cheaper type of construction, inadequate transportation to southern and western parts.
inhab_type: Clerical, skilled mechanics, factory workers, laborers

notes: The western part of this area is bounded by Van Lindley Park and quite a few new homes are now being built mostly by home owners. The section along Walker Ave. towards the east is the older part of the area and adjoins North Carolina College for Women, this being considered a favorable influence.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales & Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: All city conveniences, adequate transportation, schools and churches in the area, community business center also located in area.
detr_influences: Nothing particular
inhab_type: Business men, professional men, clerical, skilled mechanics

notes: This section is populated by the wealthiest class in Greensboro. It contains large, substantial homes with beautiful grounds and is a highly restricted section.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H. O. L. C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Highly restricted subdivision, higher-type residences, has all city conveniences, graded school, Greensboro Country Club (private) located in area. Sufficient parks and playgrounds. As a whole contains the highest priced properties, residential, in Greensboro.
detr_influences: None
inhab_type: Executives, Business Men, and Professional Men

notes: Part of this area known as Fairfield was developed by the Fairfield Corporation just prior to the depression, and houses being on the market for sale were left on the hands of the developers. They have been rented since that time. Houses are fairly modern and attractive, and sales demand is increasing at this time. It has the possibility of a good future.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Adequate transportation, adjacent to Irving Park and graded school, all city conveniences.
detr_influences: Somewhat isolated- not near community business center.
inhab_type: Salesmen, some professional men, some clerical

notes: Information on this area applies to that part lying east of Front Street. That part west practically all belongs to the mills and there is no sales activity or mortgage lending activity.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Most all of this area west of Front Street is owned by the Cone Mill Interests, being used by employees in their mills. Therefore, there is no real estate activity in the greater portion of the area. That part east of Front Street is somewhat sparsely populated, composed largely of cheaper construction.

notes: This is known as the town of Pomona, containing Pomona Terra Cotta Plant, manufacturers of sewer pipe, also Pomona Cotton Mills. The larger portion of the population are mill workers and some reside in mill-owned properties. To the north is Highland Park West subdivision which is the better part of the area, occupied by clerical and skilled mechanics.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H.O.L.C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Nothing particular except close proximity to industrial plants wherein most of the people resident in the area earn their livelihood.
detr_influences: Location of manufacturing plants, railroad roundhouse, mill village.

notes: Same description as B8, but for higher percentage of frames and wide range of prices-age range older.
name: Richmond, Virginia

notes: This section includes Sunset Hills which is highly restricted and zoned and is one of the best residential sections in the city. In the eastern part of the section is "West Market Terrace" which is not as desirable as Sunset Hills but has the advantage of joining "Sunset Hills", the only disadvantage being that it is older and property values are not as high as in "Sunset Hills". North of Friendly Road is as yet undeveloped to a certain extent. North Carolina State College for women adjoins this section on the Southeast and is not considred as detrimental but the contrary.
source: Frank R. Hutton, Contract Sales and Management Broker, H. O. L. C.
name: Greensboro, N.C.
favor_influences: Well zoned and highly restricted, all conveniences, schools, churches, adequate transportation, community business center, uniform and modern construction, park, recreation center.
detr_influences: None
inhab_type: Executives, business men, and Professional men

notes: This is a small area, well kept up and considered a good section. It lies near Krug Park, the best in the city. Houses in the area are the large 2-story type, very hard to sell when the ancestral owners leave them.
source: Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Quinn, Mr. Schneider
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
desc_terrain: Sloped slightly from Krug Park to Savannah Road
favor_influences: Krug Park
detr_influences: Distance from business sections
peakprice: Only one sale in four years

notes: This is part of St. Joseph which was built up during the boom of 1836.  It is a large area, occupied almost entirely by modest income people.  Sales have been very low in the area during the last few years.  It is often referred to by real estate people as the "North End" which is generally referred to as a poor sales area and one which lenders avoid.  It has all types and sizes of old houses.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Peterson
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: None outstanding
detr_influences: None oustanding for the type of area it is.

notes: An old trashy area with a large number of negroes.  It runs along the Missouri River and the old wholesale district of the city and is occupied by a low class of laborers.  There have been no sales to speak of in this area for eight years and rental demand is confined to the lowest grade properties which overwhelmingly predominate in the area.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Miss Hines.
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: None
detr_influences: A section occupied by negroes and low grade white; hence such detrimental influences as the adjoining Missouri River and old wholesale district make little difference to the occupants.

notes: This is one of the oldest parts of the city.  Most of the houses in the southern one-half of it are more than 60 years old and many of them have been rooming houses for several decades.  The area has all types and sizes of houses, all old.  There is a fair rental demand for certain types of property but most of the security is so old, and so many of the houses are so large, that its peak has long since been reached and passed as a rent area.
source: Mr. Dittemore, Miss Hines, Mr. Schneider
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Close in
detr_influences: Business encroachment and resultant transition to rooming house district.
inhab_type: Some business, professional, clerical, wage earners, retired

notes: This is an area of scattered small, run-down homes occupied by workers.  It is not as old as D-1 and D-3, otherwise there is little difference in the type of property.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
detr_influences: Dirt streets

notes: On both sides of Lovers Lane in this area and on Circle Drive between Cornell and Grove, the security deserves a first grade rating but these spots are not large enough to segregate. Surrounding these sections are older houses of the one and two story type, brick, frame and stucco. In fact, the great variety of houses, large and small, some 30 years old, in the whole area detract very much from the better grade of property above mentioned. Only new houses are selling in this area which is a choice part of the city. Ever available rent house is taken and the area is in great demand for rental purposes.
source: Mr. Barrow, Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Block
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Location on higher ground than surrounding areas to the north, west and south. Newer and very good houses on Circle Drive and south of Lover's Lane (in themselves worthy of "A" rating).
detr_influences: No outstanding unfavorable influences.

desirability: Up. If some of the old houses were replaced by new ones, this would be an "A" area.
notes: This is a rather scattered area, very much suburban. It included Lovers Lane, named and immortalized by the late poet, Eugene Field, who lived and worked for a time in St. Joseph. The houses on Lovers Lane are scattered, most of them old two-story structures and a few new ones. A cemetery detracts from the Lovers Lane section. On Ashland Ave., are three of the largest, newest and best houses in St. Joseph, mansions that cost more than $35,000 each. But in other parts of the area are the older, two-story structures, well-kept and occupied by leading citizens. Should a building boom strike St. Joseph this area would be selected for the larger and better homes and could easily become a first grade section.
source: Mr. Peterson, Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Miss Hines
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
desc_terrain: Level. Gradual slopes downward on both sides of Ashland Avenue and Lover's Lane.
favor_influences: Scenic beauty, particularly along Lover's Lane with many very good sites for homes bordering on estates with suburban influence.
detr_influences: Cemetery along Lover's Lane. Old houses among larger newer ones.
build_type: A few new mansions but chiefly large old 2-story houses.
build_age: New houses all under 8 years, old ones 30 years.

notes: That portion of this area on each side of Ashland Avenue is made up of one-story rather old cottages.  The small section adjoining Ashland Cemetary compares favorably to A3 as to the grade of securty, but there is no demand for it due to the cemetary.  Sales have been negligible.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Peterson, Mr. Barrow, Mr. Dittemore.
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Suburban atmosphere - adjoining "A" and "B" areas.
detr_influences: Ashland Cemetery

notes: This is Hundley Place except that portion on each side of Ashland Avenue. It is the newest development in St. Joseph, (Hundley Place). Sales have been very slow during the last few years, hardly enough in number to set up a valuation history.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Barrow, Mr. Peterson
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Newest area in city
detr_influences: Nearby cemetery

rentdemand1: Only one rent house in the area
notes: These large houses on each side of wide Noyes Boulevard are well kept up. Lawns slope gradually from sidewalk to houses. As a group the houses in this area are the largest in the city. The area is occupied by business and professional men of the higher income brackets. There is only one house for saleat $16,000 with very little prospect of moving.
source: Mr. barrow, Mr. Peterson, Mr. Block
name: St. joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: The "swank" district of St. Jospeh. Adjoining C-4, seperated by a ridge and trees and in no way constitutes a detrimental influence.
detr_influences: None
inhab_type: The more affluent business and professional men
lowrent: Only one rent house in the area

notes: This small area is sandwiched between "A" and "B" areas, which is favorable.  However, the distinction between them is very marked.  Houses in C-4 are older, smaller and the district is not well kept up.  It is difficult to understand why this poor area amid the best sections in the city and real estate men explain that it "just happens".
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Barrow, Mr. Dittemore
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Adjoining better areas.

notes: This is Westminster Place, a small area which is beginning to show age, houses ranging from 10 to 30 years old. A few vacant lots are owned by the Tootle Estate. No sales have been made in this area for several years, save possibly one or two and values given above are more or less the asking price. There are very few rent houses, all in demand and all occupied.
source: Mr. Barrow, Mr. Peterson, Mr. Dittemore
name: St. Joseph, Mo.

rentdemand1: Only two rent houses, both occupied
notes: This is Farleigh Place, small but exclusive as to type of occupants/ It is hidden from view of the adjoining D-5 by a heavy growth of trees. The latter exercises a very little detrimental influence on it. Mr. Barrow, agent for the developer, was pessimistic over prospects of selling lots for new houses. In the area, which is small, there are probably not more than three houses for sale. The area was opened 15 years ago.
source: Mr. Barrow, agent for developer of Farleigh Place; Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Restrictions of Developers. Close to other better areas.
detr_influences: Adjoining D-5

notes: An area very difficult to grade. It would be A were it not for the age of its large two-story houses, occupied by the leading most affluent families. On the north side of Frederick covering many acres, is the Wyatt estate, one of the largest and best in western Missouri. Across the street is a new $35,000 house. The area is beautifully situated on Noyes Boulevard and Frederick Avenue. This was St. Josephs swank district, 20 years ago. Real estate men do not remember a sale in this area in the last 8 years. There is no demand whatever for the large, aging two-story structures. Furthermore, the occupants, following St. Joseph tradition, do not care to move from their well-established homes. There is no new exclusive area in St. Joseph to which this class of occupants would move.
source: Mr. Barrow, Mr. Quinn, Mr. Peterson, Mr. Block
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Surrounding "A" areas. Location on Noyes Boulevard. Natural beauty of area. Suburban atmosphere.
detr_influences: No major ones.
price1929: No sales. These structures would be priced at about $10,000 but would not sell at that.

notes: This is an old section undoubtedly the best of the "D" areas from the standpoint of the desirability, security, type of occupants, and virtually every other angle.  It is a typical area of all sizes and types of houses.  Forty years ago, it was the swank district.  Many of the city's most prominent business people live there, occupying their old houses.  There are several wealthy men still residing in this area, preserving St. Joseph's tradition.  In 1929 a few houses sold for from $13,000 to $20,000 but they were isolated cases.  Today it is a very desirable rent area with houses and apartments much in demand but sales have been almost nil in the last 5 or 6 years.
source: Miss Hines, Mr. Block, Mr. Quinn
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Reasonably close in with a certain "aristocracy" which makes it desirable
inhab_type: Business & professional men, executives, clerical workers

notes: An old, close-in area where rental demand is good but sales negligible.  Some of the city's first large houses are found in this area.  These have been in use as long as 70 years.  It is something of an apartment and rooming house area.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Miss Hines
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Proximity to business district
detr_influences: Age of property - Business encroachments

notes: This district is typical of St. Joseph with all types and sizes in homes ranging in age from new to 50 years.  There are many substantial houses less than 20 years old which cost upwards of $10,000, but their values are much depreciated by the many small, old cottages, even "shacks".  In this area are some small, new houses put up with second-hand material.  The area has all types of occupants including business and professional men, high salaried executives and many low income people.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Barrow, Mr. Peterson
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
detr_influences: Lack of uniformity in construction, cheap construction among the good - much old property.

notes: This is one of the better residential areas of St. Joseph. Were it not for the lack of uniformity and the age of some of the structures, it would deserve an A rating. The best properties in the area are along the wide Noyes Boulevard (28th Street). With its large expensive homes, this area has displayed very little sales activity.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Peterson, Mr. Barrow, Miss Hines
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Landscaping and natural beauty along Noyes Boulevard
rent1929: Very few rent houses at from $35 to $75 a month

notes: This is Brookdale, the best in St. Joseph from a sales standpoint. It is also an area where the rental demand is strong. Last year's sales included new houses. The area is occupied by a good class of people, business and professional men of moderate incomes.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Peterson, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Block
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
detr_influences: None outstanding

notes: This is an area wherein houses are older than those in adjoining 3-5.  A good class of people live herein, largely families of working men, some executives and clerical workers.  A few sales were made in the area in 1929 but hardly any since that time.
source: Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Schneider, Mr. Block
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
detr_influences: Distance from business section

notes: This area contains the heaviest negro concentration of St. Joseph, also a reasonably large number of foreigners.  The range of rentals given above applies only west of 22nd Street.  East of 22nd rents which ranged from $30 to $50 in 1929 run from $25 to $35 today despite a sprinkling of Negroes therein.  The area is old, with all types and sizes of construction.
source: Mr. Block, Mr. Quinn, Mr. Schneider, Mr. Dittemore
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
detr_influences: Negro District
inhab_type: Negroes, laborers, low income wage earners

notes: An area with one-story cottages predominating, occupied by a good class of people.  It is set apart from adjoining D-7 (negro district) and D-10 because of a better grade of security and a higher class of occupants.  However, like most of the St. Joseph areas, it has a wide variety of types of houses, also all classes of occupants.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Block, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Peterson
name: St. Joseph, Mo.

rent_act: Good, by low income workers only
notes: This large area has a variety of types of old houses but one-story cottages predominate.  It is entirely a laboring man's area.  Houses from 12th Street to the railroad tracks are very poor type of shacks, housing relief families, low wage earners.  East of 12th Street and in the southern part of the area are a better class of occupants and better class of property.  There have been a few sales in the better type of houses.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Block
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
detr_influences: Adjoining industrial plants and railroad yards are detrimental from the standpoint of desirability, but an advantage to this area is it is occupied entirely by workers from industrial plants and railroads.
black: Very few on west side near railroad tracks
yr_current: Few in better parts of area

notes: An area with the typical St. Joseph variety of all sizes and types of houses, from 10 to 50 years old.  That portion along Agency has some good homes, well kept, although not entirely built up.
source: Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Block, Mr. Schneider, Mr. Quinn
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Adjoins Bartlett Park, not far from golf course
detr_influences: No outstanding ones

notes: This area has a favorable influence in Bartlett Park. It is attractive in appearance, all houses well kep up. It is one of the newest areas in city. Sales values quoted above apply chiefly to new houses. No sales of older houses in the area. This is an attractive area where home ownership is very high.
source: Mr. Schneider, Mr. Block, Mr. Quinn
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Bartlett Park and golf course only short distance away.

notes: A respectable residential area occupied by the typical St. Joseph run of business, professional, clerical workers and some laborers.  There are all types and mixes of homes.  It is an area well preserved and of good appearance.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Block, Mr. Schneider
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: Close to Bartlett Park, golf course

notes: A small area of scattered acre tracts and gardens, occupied by low income workers, truck gardners, etc.  Streets are unpaved, houses are small, old shacks.
source: Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Schneider, Mr. Quinn
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
detr_influences: No paving

notes: This area adjoining the railroad yards and industrial, wholesale plants, houses the lowest type of people in St. Joseph.  In the north end is the Mexican concentration.  It is the heaviest relief section of the city.  Home ownership is very low, sales are nil.  Houses are all old, frame one and two story structures, terribly run down.  They are merely shacks housing the type of occupants found in such areas.
source: Mr. Block, Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: None
detr_influences: Adjoining railroad yards, wholesale and industrial area.

notes: This small area was opened for development some 12 to 16 years ago, by Nate Block and was designed to be a section of houses for industrial workers in St. Joseph and South St. Joseph.  Its development was arrested by lack of demand.  It is made up largely of acre tracts.  According to consultants, whose names appear below, the proposed sale of an HOLC house for $3100 (approved August 15, 1937) is the first sign of a sale in the area for several years.  The section was hard hit because of the downward trend in industrial employment, hence the high proportion of relief people in the section.
source: Mr. Block, developer of the tract; Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Smith
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
lowprice: No sales in last four years

notes: This is Florence Addition, occupied by very low income, low-grade white people, a few negro families and a few foreigners.  There is no sales at all in the area.  It is a small area.
source: Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Quinn, Mr. Block
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
favor_influences: None
detr_influences: Condition of houses, all old frame shacks receiving no rehabilitation whatever.  Location, being rather isolated but not far from packing plants.

notes: This is a small area on a hillside, sloping down toward King Hill Avenue.  The type of construction is quite uniform, one-story and two-story frame houses built to attract workingmen from the nearby industrial plants.  Due to the distance from schools, it is not attractive to workers with families including children of school age.  There have been virtually no sales during the last few years.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Block
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
desc_terrain: Sloping the area is on a hillside
detr_influences: Distance from schools

notes: This is South St. Joseph, exclusively a working man's section.  Although a part of St. Joseph, it is off to itself with its own railroad yards, post-office, three banks and two business districts.  This area was started in 1888 and grew to almost its present proportions 10 years later when the three packing plants (only two now) adjoining it made this one of the largest meat packing centers of the world at that time.  The area has suffered terribly from a real estate standpoint due to the slump in packing plant employment.  Sales are not made and rents are very definitely fixed at $20 to $22 a month for a small frame cottage.  There is not a $30-a-month house in the entire section.  There are many relief families in the area, including a good number for whom the Welfare Board pays $8 a month rent.
source: Glen Brumbaugh, South St. Joseph banker, Mr. Smith, Mr. Block, Mr. Dittemore
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
desc_terrain: Level.  East end slopes slightly toward hill
favor_influences: Area has all modern conveniences.
detr_influences: Close to stockyards and packing plants.  This constitutes unfavorable factor from standpoint of desirability of living conditions but it is an area suited to house workers in these plants.

notes: This area lies alongside a hill which adds to its desirability as a section in which to live, but the large old houses have no sales demand. The sale values given above are more or less estimates of values. There has been no volume on which to base any definite conclusion.
source: Mr. Quinn, Mr. Dittemore, Mr. Peterson
name: St. Joseph, Mo.
inhab_type: Retired, clerical, some business and professional

notes: Ground rents in this section range from $36 to 60. Average $42. Properties around Johns Hopkins Hospital are better than the average and have considerable desirability in housing hosipital attendants and for commercial value Ground rents on broadway. Sales are very property. Section east of broadway is better. southern section largely industry. Whole section is spotty.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Proximity to employment, industrial and commercial
detr_influences: Heavy concentration of foreigners. Property is in very bad state of repair.

notes: The entire area is populated principally by persons of Polish extraction who have considerable pride of appearance of their property. Age of property necessitates the third grade. Ground rents in this area range from 42-72 and 42-48 predominatly.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Proximity to Patterson Park. Near to industrial plants.
detr_influences: Substantial age and disadvantages of industry except on above

notes: Ground rents range from$48-$75 and average $60.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Fairly desirable residential area of old houses. Close to commercial area.
detr_influences: Old style architecture

notes: Area becomes worse south of eastern avenue. Ground rents range $36-60. Predominately $36-48. Mixture of small industrial plants. Properties are old but fairly well maintained.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Close to industrial employment
detr_influences: Mixture of foreign born. Disadvantage of industry except as above.

notes: Ground rents range from$75 to 150 and average $90-110. Some of these properties are being converted into small apartment units and others are being used as boarding houses.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Close to commercial area. Goucher college located in the section. Desirable location.
detr_influences: Industrial plants. Continuing obsolescence of old property.

notes: Ground rents range $30-60. Predominating $43-48. Vandalism in this section.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Near desirable properties.
detr_influences: Houses in very bad condition. Many alley properties Area is rundown.

notes: Many high-grade apartments are located along Charles and St. Paul streets. Ground rents range from $90-150, Predominating $120.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Stable old residential section of good character.
detr_influences: None

notes: A recent development with much room for expansion directly to the north. Ground rent $90-120. Average $110. Much of this property has been built in the last five years, especially that on northern edge. Valuation changes do not include these properties..
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore, MD
favor_influences: Fairly new Suburban area of homogenus character. Well planned development. Fairly close to city shopping area. Near parks. Near schools.
detr_influences: None
currentrent: Only limited number of rental units
rent1929: Only limited number of rental units
lowrent: Only limited number of rental units

desirability: Downward as residential, upward for commerce
notes: Ground rents 72-120. average 90.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Conversion value of location for business purposes. Commercial future.
detr_influences: Heavy traffic and disadvantage of commerce except as above.
build_type: Cottages on east side rows on west side

notes: Mostly fee properties. A few homes valued at $10,000 to 15,000 along Houseland Avenue with ground rent up to $150.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore, MD
favor_influences: Very nicely planned residential area of medium to large homes. Direct transportation to center of city is good. Close to business area on Greenmount Ave.
detr_influences: None
currentrent: Only limited number of rental units
rent1929: Only limited number of rental units
lowrent: Only limited number of rental units

notes: Ground rents $72-100. Ground rents in Cedarcroft are principally 120.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore, MD
favor_influences: Good residential area holding up in value.
detr_influences: None

notes: Owned and controlled by the Roland Park Company. Developers apparently intend to keep the section comparable to Guilford. All fee property.
name: Baltimore, MD
favor_influences: To be developed as high grade development
detr_influences: None

notes: Ground rents range from $72 to 95. Predominating $72.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore, MD
favor_influences: Homogenous development. Near to parks. Transportation is good. All modest homes in good demand.
detr_influences: None

notes: This section was completely built up in 1921. All fee properties. Houses are hard to sell in this section but character of area is good.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore, MD
favor_influences: Desirable residential section. Principally large homes well restricted.
detr_influences: No

notes: Ground rents range $42 to 90. Predominating $60-72 Not a very desirable area.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore
favor_influences: Old residential section of modest character in poor condition. Near Druid Hill Park.
detr_influences: Heavy obsolescence of property

notes: Ground rents 60-90. Predominating 84. Fair valuation.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore, MD
favor_influences: Stable Residential section of modest homes
detr_influences: None

notes: Principally fee property. This section lies in Baltimore County outside Baltimore City Originally developed as expensive section, but recent houses have been lower priced, thus holding down values in higher priced units.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore, MD
favor_influences: Good residential area. Well planned.
detr_influences: Distance to city

notes: This section lies in baltimore county just outside of baltimore city. Ground rent 90-120. Principally 90. New houses are up to 10,000.
source: Louis Kroner, property review appraiser H.O.L.C.
name: Baltimore, Metropolitan area
favor_influences: Fairly good residential section with all conviences.
detr_influences: Distance to center of city

notes: Ground rents range 72-90. Predominating. The general reputation of this section is fair.but the section embraces some poorly constructed houses.

name: Winston-Salem, N.C.
favor_influences: Development in this area consists almost entirely of cheap construction, and there is very little development of any kind. The city sewerage disposal plant is located a short distance South of the area.

notes: Southern part very old section-4th and 5th semi-business & fair residential section- certain parts of West Salem on Walnut, Green, & Broad Sts. still contain some good properties which are well maintained. Remainder cheap rental property. 4th & 5th also have some large residences. This section comprises the main portion of the town formerly Salem and many of the properties are very old. The Moravian Church office is also located in it. It also contains some very fine old homes in W. Fifth St. adjacent to the business ssection.
source: H.K. Ogburn, Real Estate Sales Broker and Property Mangement Broker, H.O.L.C.

detr_influences: Smoke from factories. Old properties.

Fourteenth St. formerly occupied by white people but in late years they ahve moved away and this street now contains many good colored homes. Population north of 21st. St. almost entirely white.

detr_influences: Age and obsolescence. Old part of town.
build_repair: old and in need of repair

desirability: In slow decline because of age and obsolescence.
notes: N/A

detr_influences: Age and proximity to industry

name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: none
detr_influences: Practically none of these homes are equipped with flush toilets. Houses crowded. No sewers. Only Highland Avenue and Penn Street are paved.
build_repair: Fair to poor. Probably 35% need structural repairs.

notes: N/A
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
desc_terrain: Flat. This area is called "Austin Heights."
favor_influences: none
detr_influences: Farms on three sides. Approach through Whitley, a very poor area. No sewers. Outside the city.

notes: N/A
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: none
detr_influences: Strictly foreign. Wire workers from the Indiana Steel & Wire Co. Belgians and Hungarians.

notes: "Tenderloin" district.
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: none
detr_influences: old section. Bordering on industry.

notes: Properties: Willard Street south to Ninth, between Hackley and Ebright Streets are in very good condition, as are the properties from First to Willard between Wolfe and Lincoln. Properties from Second to Seventh, between Macedonia and Shipley are in very poor condition.
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: Close to factory work
detr_influences: Soot and smoke from industry. Close to "Red" area.

notes: Condition of properties notably poor along Liberty Street, and notably good along Hackley Street.
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: Near to business center
detr_influences: N/A

notes: Properties are in good condition from Memorial Drive to 14th Street between Walnut and Mulberry Streets, and also from 14th to 18th Streets between Mulberry and Jefferson Streets. Otherwise, fair to poor.
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: none
detr_influences: none outstanding. Fair labor neighborhood.

notes: Lots average about $200. Properties are in good condition from 14th to 16th Streets, between Grant an Penn Streets. Grant is the only street developed. Except for the homes facing Memorial Drive, there are not more than 25 homes in the area.
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: None
detr_influences: Proximity to industry

notes: N/A
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: none
detr_influences: Not half the structures are equipped with flush toilets. Homes are crowded.
build_repair: From fair to very poor. West of Walnut Street very poor.

desirability: Good for those who want to be near to business, but generally on the decline.
notes: The two blocks -- Jackson to Charles between Liberty and Franklin -- are above the average of the area in maintenance. Charles and Council Street are valued at $5,000. Very few properties changed hands during the depression.
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: Close to business center
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence

notes: As far south as 8th St. in the area marked "White City" structural conditions are good. Columbia Heights is practically undeveloped. In Rosemont both sides of 14th St. are good -- west of May Avenue and from 14th to 16th between Manhattan and Biltmore. In Burlington Heights property condition is good from Memorial Drive to 14th between Waldmere and Eaton. The whole area is thinly settled.
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
desc_terrain: Flat. Called "White City" -- Columbia Heights, Rosemont and Burlington Heights.
favor_influences: none
detr_influences: Most homes without flush toilets. Homes crowded. No water. Streets are not paved.
build_type: single units of 4 & 5 rms and bungalow type

notes: Property condition poor between Janny and New York Avenues. Entire area declining because of cheap construction though only ten years old. Better homes are along Bethel Avenue and are shown in yellow.
source: N/A
name: Muncie, Indiana
favor_influences: None
detr_influences: Houses very generally do not have flush toilets. No sewers. No basements.

notes: Outside city limits. Have local water and sewerage system. Bus transportation only fair. Known as Raynor Park.
source: Ed. Dailey Service Dept., HOLC. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet
name: Joliet, Illinois
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Lack of nearby school facilities.

notes: During depression nothing at all moving here. Nobody but foreigners would buy in this area and they were out of work and had no money to purchase. South of Theodore, west of Clement sparsely settled. North of Theodore is Lockport Township, balance of area is outside city limits - class of people living here won't live anywhere else.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years is real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Illinois
favor_influences: Convenient to North Broadway industries. Transportation fair.
detr_influences: No sewer or water facilities. Some smoke from factories.

notes: On Prairie Avenue and Raynor, and on Kelly, sewer and water faciltities are in and homes are of substantial character. There are many old frame homes interspersed throughout the area, but mainly east of Kelly. Part of the extreme southern part of area is inside city limits (south of Curtis).
source: Ed. Dailey. HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Jolliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Lacks sewer and waiter.
build_constr: Newer houses are brick Older houses are frame

notes: Vacant lots are in fair demand in this area. On Campbell and Wilcox is a brick apartment of 20 units, well kept up. Around Raynor and Mason are 3 brick apartments from 5-8 units, well kept up. And there are several 2 unit brick and a few frame interspersed throughout the area. Best of Raynor and south of Western is oldest part of area, and from Prairie west there are no pavements except Western which is paved to Reed St, otherwise area has all utilities. The western part of area from Reed St, to Midland Ave. between Mayfield and Glenwood has temporary sewers only reported as being remedied by W. P. A. at this time. There are many old frame homes interspersed throughout the area. The extremes N. W. section of area is outside city limits. All section of area marked undeveloped on the west has no city sewers or water.
source: Ed. Dailey HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Illinois
desc_terrain: Level, clay, gravel and stone. Rolling land east of Wilcox with many old shade trees.
favor_influences: Farragut School, and trend of growth in this area, and west.
detr_influences: None.
build_constr: Older houses are frame and new are brick
build_repair: Fair, as regards frame Good as regards brick

notes: Because of lack of city sewer and water some cheaper cottages were built without basements. However, the future prospects of the area are good, just as soon as the foregoing is rectified.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate business and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Illinois
favor_influences: Bordering the best part of Joliet.
detr_influences: No restrictions, no city sewer or water. However, this matter is now under consideration.

notes: Vacant lots are in fair demand in this area. Taft School (grade school) is comparatively new. Have septic sewers and field drains. Water systems O.K. No paving except State Highway $30. Known as Biragate and Kerwin Terrace. Outside City Limits
source: Ed. Dailey. HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Illinois
favor_influences: Have own sewer and water system.
detr_influences: None.

notes: There is a better demand for cheap homes than others, i.e. those selling for less than $3,000 and the recovery of this class has been more satisfactory. Known as Idleside Subdivision and surrounded by truck gardens and farm lands. Has good grade school in souther part. Outside city limits.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate business and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: None. On Trey Road, Route 69.
detr_influences: No improvements, sewers, water, or public transportation.

notes: From Midland west mostly American Cam and steel mill workers, and almost entirely foreigners. Also along Meadow east of Midland to Wheeler are industrial workers. North of Belleview sparsely built up. Bordering West Park on the north is one home reported to have sold for $50,000 prior to 1929, another bordering West Park on the west is offered at $30,000, and to south of park are 3 or 4 homes of an estimated cost of $6,000. Known as Rockdale Section and West Park. Outside city limits.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage busienss in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Illinois
favor_influences: West Park.
detr_influences: Close to industrial development.
build_type: Single 5-6 R, a few 2 unit apts., bus. & res. combined
build_age: east of Midland, 40 yrs. west of Midland, 15 yrs.

notes: From Oneida to Troy Road between Williams and Reed and west to O'Neil Street, there is sewer and water, but otherwise from Troy south, with the exception of Park Drive and May between Troy Road and Marion, these utilities do not exist. With the exception of the northeastern corner, the area is sparsely settled. Known as Reed Woods.
source: Ed Dailey. HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet
name: Joliet, Illinois
desc_terrain: Level -- except from Morgan Street south and Reed west which is rough and wooded.
favor_influences: Convenient to West Park.
detr_influences: Lacking in sewer and water facilities. No paved streets, in fact, streets generally poor.

notes: The extreme western section of area bounded by Wheeler and Rayner, Morgan and Marion is new subdivision (8 years old) and is the only part of entire area not paved. This section is under development and is restricted, being best available section of area close in. New construction is mostly in this section of area on extreme west now marked "sparsely settled".
source: Ed Dailey. HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Illinois
desc_terrain: Level - a gradual rise from Center Street to Hunter -- a ravine runs along Emmett and Washington to Hunter.
detr_influences: North of Washington to Jefferson from Garfield to Wilcox is a cemetery. Proximity to industrial district. Canal to east.
inhab_type: Mixed, clerks, business, professional, mechanics, etc.
build_type: Old single frame 5-8 R, and few converted to duplexes in eastern section

notes: A few colored families scattered throughout southern part of area. On West Park Avenue from Raynor to Wheeler is a better class of mixed construction homes averaging $4000 to $4500. From Raynor to Wheeler and from Morgan to Croghan there are no sewers or water facilities except those privately owned.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Illinois
desc_terrain: Level. Rock foundation, very little soil on surface, but from Raynor west soil is clay loan and deeper to rock.
favor_influences: Convenient to downtown business section.
detr_influences: Due to Brandon Locks on river, Chicago refuse slows up and is a cause of extreme bad odors.

notes: All improvements are in. Pavements good. On account of proximity to downtown business center it is popular for residential purposes. Assessment of property is reported as unusually high in this area, and subject of unfavorable comment due to incompetent assessors.
source: Ed. Dailey. HOLC Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet
name: Joliet, Illinois
desc_terrain: Level of northwestern part of area from Douglas north and Center on east. From Hickory west to Center is sloping.
favor_influences: Proximity to schools, churches, and downtown business center.
detr_influences: None, except elder district.
inhab_type: Mixed, clerks, mechanics, laborers, business, & professional
build_type: Single, 5-8 rooms, duplexes - few 2 unit (brick) apts

notes: An old neighborhood, very desirable for the present class of resident. Limited mortgage loans are made here.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet
name: Joliet, Illinois
desc_terrain: Level, gravel subsoil, clay and stone.
favor_influences: Have all utilities, close to schools, industry, and churches.
detr_influences: None.
build_type: Single 5-7 R, few apts. 2 units scattered through area

notes: This area running from Granite St. on teh north to Wheeler on the south is alsong the canal, and railroad at DeKalb Street. This is the oldest part of Joliet and was the first business section in the early days. Store and flat building begin at Spring on the north and extend to Washington on the south. From Washington south it is very sparsely settled.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
desc_terrain: Level, but midway between Broadway and Bluff commence a perpendicular drop to the river (in places) - from Ruby to Marion. Theose who own property in this area claim they are building for the desk purposes lacking to future development of the waterway.
detr_influences: Many old disapidated buildings.
build_type: Single 5-9 R, 2 story-housewith store & flat bldgs.

notes: 6 or 7 negro families on Berry Street. Smoke from Illinois Coke plants very bad. That portion south of Roseland to southern boundary of area is in Joliet Township outside city limits. The majority of better class homes are scattered around Lockport Road and Bruce Road. Known as Foresent Park and Fairmont. North of Roseland outside city limits -- in Lockport Township.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
desc_terrain: All level except that section between Barry and Oxford, and Hawthorne west to State Route 4-A which is very rough. Poor garden ground.
detr_influences: Close to State Penitentiary and industries. No improvements, poor streets, undeveloped.

notes: Between Briggs, east side of Peel, they have own water and sewerage system, also a few dozen homes on Hibbard Street have own sewerage and water system. Otherwise, with a few private owner exceptions, area is without public water or sewerage system except from Clairmont to Cherry Hill Road which has own water and sewerage system. Known as East Moreland and Elm Highlands. There are some more substantial homes, averaging today $6,500, brick and frame, along Washington Street. Close to Culberton School on west. Mostly wallpaper employees reside here. Adjacency to wallpaper mills favorable to them. East of C-8 is the Cherry Hill Subdivision restricted to single units and from $5,500 to $11,500.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
