name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: None, except good schools.
detr_influences: Lacking in public improvements and building restrictions.
build_type: 1 family 3-8 rooms, three 2-apt. units along Washington St, frame

notes: Colored people are on Cleveland and Chase Avenue west of Lloyd. Meeker Street is only street in area with pavement. City sewers and water are only on property situated between Cleveland and williamson and Collins and city limits on east. Part of area on north and east is outside city limits, and also part of south-eastern corner.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
desc_terrain: Level, except east of Charlesworth which is somewhat rough.
favor_influences: Convenient to steel mill and Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railroad.
detr_influences: Smoke from industries, foreign element.

notes: From Jackson Street south is better part of area as to present day values. Some brick apartments of 6-8 units and 3 or 4 with 4 units interspersed in the southern and eastern part of area. The northern part of Jackson has depreciated badly because of foreign influx. A great many of the old Swedish people started in this area and built some fine homes but are now being edged out by foreigners.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: Close to downtown business section, convenient to all east side industries. Has all public utilities.
detr_influences: Negroes to west of area and influx of foreigners from north.
inhab_type: Laborers, some business, few professional, etc.

notes: Only paved streets are Jackson and Columbia. A very undesirable section. Increase of land values is remote. Many of the old frame houses, while not converted into duplexes are used for two or more families.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: Close to downtown business section.
detr_influences: Colored section.

newconstr_type: A few homes $5,000 cost (brick) under construction
notes: There are a few scattered brick homes in the vicinity between Jackson and Columbia on Landau and Henderson. From Jackson south there are city water and community sewers. " " north " " no city water or sewerage systems. A desirable section for these foreigners to live. They like it.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: Close to east side industries and downtown business section.
detr_influences: Railroad yards - noisiy and smoky.
build_type: Single 5-10 R, a few duplexes converted out of old large homes

notes: No Sewerage or city water. The entire area is sparsely settled. However, the area along Washington Street and Norten are built up. Outside city limits.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Industries, railroads, creek.

notes: There is one apartment on Richards Street (brick) of 54 units, 3 stories high. Around Albert and that part of Wilson north of Second Avenue and also that section of area south Bowen, there are no paved streets and buildins are of cheaper construction and ill-kept. There is a pronounced Italian settlement south of 4th Avenue between Sherman and Gardener extending to the Creek at the south. This area was once regarded as the best in the city. That part of area between 1st Avenue on north and 5th Avenue on sotuh, bounded by Mississippi on east and Sherman on west is somewhat better than the balance and loans are made here today. However, interspersed throughout the entire area are many old large frame houses needing repair and paint.
source: Ed Dailey. HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: Adjacent to downtown business center. Good schools, good transportation, conveneint to Nowell Park.
detr_influences: Sewerage empties into Hickory Creek. Smoke from railroads.
build_type: Single 6-12 R, duplexes scattered thruout area except in extreme south

notes: Convenient to east side industries, schools, downtown district. Known as Brooklyn.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joleit.
name: Joliet, Illinois
favor_influences: Best east side residential property convenient to downtown business district.
detr_influences: None.

notes: At 2nd Avenue and Boulder, there is an apartment (brick) of 30 units (3 rooms). The recovery is better in the northeastern section of area. In the south of area recovery has been little. The whole area is outside the city. No sewers or water system except private wells. Some mortgage loans will be made here upon big margins of safety. Outside city limits, in Joliet Township.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years is real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: Close to east side industries. Good schools.
detr_influences: Railroads and deserted quarry on southeast and colored people on Bennett and Lehnan Streets.
build_type: Single 3-4-6 R, few duplexes on Linden

notes: Colored people are thick in the extreme southern section of area, south of Mills Road and east of Rowell. There are also some colored families in Bennett and Lehman Streets on north. A new grade school is being built on Rowell Avenue, South of C-14 and sout hof Mills Road is a Swedish Orphans' House and House for the Aged. There are some better homes around here owned by native-born Americans. Outside city limits.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Colored people, railroads, and smoke from industries.

notes: Immediately north of Mills Road and west of Richards there is construction now of ceme block homes. A chicago building contracter is reported as having bought 50 lots and is building these cement homes to sell at $4,700 each, Northwestern section of area is known as Clearview. Outside city limits, in Joliet Township.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
desc_terrain: Level. Sloping land to Manhattan Road.
favor_influences: None - except Rowell Park to West.
detr_influences: Railroads, oil refining industry. Distant to schools.
build_constr: Frame on north & brick in extreme south

notes: Known as Greenfield Subdivision. Have own water system. Poor transportation. A new grade school is being built within one-fourth of a mile of this subdivision - to south. Outside city limits, in Joliet Township.
source: Ed Dailey, Holc Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Colored settlement to south.

notes: The northern part of area only is developed with homes -- the southern part is unimproved and not in demand for farms or anything else, except some truck gardens along Oakview Avenue on east. outside city limits
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Illinois
favor_influences: Close to wallpaper mills.
detr_influences: Railroads, smoke from industries, no sewers or water, borders cemetery.

notes: No restrictions whatever. Section east of Briggs is approximately 15 years old. Section west of " " " 30 " " with some substantial homes interspersed throughout. Silver Cross Hospital is located in northwestern corner of area and is considered a desirable asset. outside city limits in Joliet Township.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
desc_terrain: High and rolling and level, well wooded.
favor_influences: Adjoining Highland Park. Community-owned wells.
detr_influences: Smoke from railroads on west. No sewers or water facilties, no paved streets.
inhab_type: Mixed, better class laborers, mostly R.R. men

notes: The only houses in this area are between Briggs and Pickwick, except these built along U.S. Highway 30. Outside city limits.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Industries, cemeteries, and railraods.

notes: North of Hickory Creek to city limits there are mostly Italians and many truck gardens. On north and of U. S. Highway 66 is a large stone quarry. Colored people are interspersed throughout area but mostly south of Hickory Creek. Odors from the canal and creek are bad. North of Hickory Creek is lowland with big retaining wall along the Illinois-Michigan Canal. Befuse from Chicago drainage system collects here and below the Brandon Locks the Joliet refuseis emptied. All land south of creek is rough and unsuitable for cultivation with some exceptions. American Cyanamid and Chemical Corporation and Blocksen Chemical Company are located in south of this area.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
desc_terrain: Level, some rolling land on south and west.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Canal and Hickory Creek odors, chemical odors, railroads, colored people, etc.

notes: Some homes on Ottawa and Eastern Avenue have been converted into rooming houses and apartments. Italians predominate from Water to Chicago Street south of McDonough and have built some good brick homes in the past 12 years. Colored people are scattered throughout the entire area. The only paved streets in area are Ottawa, and Eastern Avenue and Chicago Street to city limits on south. Known as 6th Ward.
source: Ed Dailey, HOLC Service Dept. 10 years in real estate and brokerage business in Joliet.
name: Joliet, Ill.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Colored, industries, railroads, Lowland south of McDonough.

notes: Nearly all green area
name: Richmond, Virginia

notes: This is a typical beach resort including a fair sized amusement park. Dwellings vary materially in size although plots are small. Area is in very run down condition.
source: See explanations
name: West Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Outlook over water.
detr_influences: Entire character of development.

notes: Dwellings in this area were originally constructed for summer use, but are now occupied, for the most part, all the year round. Houses vary from cheap bungalows to homes of fair size. Plots are generally small. Some properties are considerably above the average. Mortgage lenders are very choosey in the selection of loans.
source: See Explanations
name: West Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low, flat land rising slightly from the water.
favor_influences: Attractive view of Long Island Sound.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city, schools, and shopping center.

notes: This was once a very popular shore development but, by degrees, has lost its desirability. Homes vary from small bungalows to singles of fair size, but doubles predominate. Plots are small and the houses are built closely together. Many are badly in need of repair. Lenders are wary of this area.
source: See Explanations
name: West Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low, flat land with shaded streets.
favor_influences: Near or adjacent to water.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of dwellings.

notes: This is, generally, an older residential section with houses of various sizes and lots in preportion. Because of age, this area rates a low "B" despite the fact that properties are well maintained. North of Elm Street is not as desirable and suffers somewhat from odors from a fat rendering plant to the east. The railroad acts as a barrier between this and the hazardous section to the north. New loans are carefully scrutinized.
source: See Explanations
name: West Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low, flat land with shaded streets.
favor_influences: Convenient to central shopping center and waterfront.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: This is a somewhat newer, residential development. Houses and lots are of modest size. Architecture is varied and pleasing. Pride of ownership is evident. The railroad forms a natural barrier between this and the far less desirable section to the north.
source: See Explanations
name: West Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Land rises slightly from the south and becomes rolling. Area is well wooded.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of outlook and development.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: This is an older section of the city containing closely built houses ranging from small singles to fair sized doubles. Many houses need repairs and pride of ownership is almost entirely absent. This area is not a favorite with mortgage lenders.
source: See Explanations
name: West Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Character of improvement and occupant, as well as distance from center of city.

notes: This is a more densely settled section of mixed singles and doubles as well as a scattering of factories. The entire section is in a rather dilapidated condition.
source: See explanations
name: West Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: None, save convenience to places of employment.
detr_influences: Character of improvement and occupant, as well as lack of sewers.

notes: This is a sparsely settled section of shacks and small singles of which many are surrounded by truck gardens and vineyards. Many of the streets are on paper only and there is difficulty of ingress and egress.
source: See explanations
name: West Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Room for expansion.
detr_influences: Character of neighborhood, lack of all improvements, and distance from center of city, schools, stores, etc.

notes: This is an older section of the city containing various sized singles, doubles and a few apartments. In the southern section, many old families still reside and here pride of ownership is more in evidence. In general, houses are on fair sized plots so that houses are not built too closely together. Because of age of this area, it is not popular among lenders.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low, flat land with shaded streets.
favor_influences: Convenient to center of city.
detr_influences: Age of dwellings as well as bad odors from the south where there is a rubber plant situated.

notes: This is an old section of the city containing a few singles but doubles and multi-family dwellings predominate. Area is now given over to the laboring class and is rapidly filling up with Negros. Vandalism may be expected.
source: See explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Convenient to center of city.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of dwellings as well as type and character of occupant.

notes: This is a section of the city containing a mixture of one and two family houses of which the former range from small to fair sized dwellings. Plots are not extensive and pride of ownership is spotty. There is a sprinkling of manufacturing plants in which the inhabitants are employed. Thinness of sales market makes lenders wary of this area.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Generally flat land which is slightly higher in the north.
favor_influences: Convenient to places of employment and not too far from center of city.
detr_influences: Age of dwellings as well as sprinkling of manufacturing plants.

notes: This is a slightly older section of the city containing fair sized singles on good sized plots which are well and attractively landscaped. There are a few doubles and triples but these do not affect the desirability of the neighborhood. Some properties are decidedly above the average and these do not appear in the rental market.
source: See explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Character of development and convenient to small, central shopping center.
detr_influences: None, save distance form center of city.
build_type: Singles and a few doubles & triples

notes: This is a newer development. Most are modest single family homes of varied but pleasing architecture and located on quite small plots. There are a few two family houses as well as some quite large singles. The latter are owner occupied and do not appear in the rental market. The area is looked upon with favor by mortgage lenders.
source: See explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Slightly high, rolling and wooded land.
favor_influences: Character of development.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: This is a sparsely settled section containing almost nothing but small houses and shacks, surrounded by truck gardens and vineyards. Its only value is to those who want to go in for small sized farming.
source: See explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Character of improvement.

notes: This is a sparsely settled section containing almost nothing but small houses and shacks surrounded by truck gardens and vineyards. Its only value is to those who want to go in for small sized farming.
source: See Explanations
name: Woodbridge, Conn
favor_influences: None.
detr_influences: Character of improvement.

notes: This is a newer development of which the architecture is varied and pleasing. The houses are not built too closely together and are well cared for. Were it not for the fact that this area is entirely Jewish, it would command a higher rating.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Newness and attractiveness of development.
detr_influences: Type of inhabitants.

notes: This is an older section of the city now given over largely to Negros employed as domestics. Dwellings vary from small singles to multi-family. Section is quite congested and gives the appearance of a slum area. Absence of market has resulted in some demolition. Section is subject to vandalism.
source: See explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Flat land with tree lined streets.
favor_influences: Convenient to center of city.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of dwellings as well as character of development and inhabitant.

notes: This area contains a mixture of singles, doubles, triples and a scattering of apartments located on comparatively small plots. Inhabitants are mostly employed in adjacent Winchester Plant and are skilled mechanics. Pride of ownership is decidedly spotty.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Flat land with trees lined streets.
favor_influences: Convenient to places of employment and center of city.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of dwellings.

notes: This is a section of small singles and larger doubles occupied mainly by laborers in the nearby industrial area. Although plots are generally small some include truck gardens and vineyards.
source: See Explanations
name: Hamden, Conn.
favor_influences: Convenient to places of employment.
detr_influences: Character of improvement and distance from center of city.

notes: This is an area containing a mixture of new and old moderate sized singles and doubles with plots in proportion to size of house. It is an extremely desirable tract of land for those who work in manufacturing plants along the railroad tracks. This area rates a high "Yellow" and lenders find it a worthwhile section for their money provided a certain amount of caution be taken.
source: See Explanations
name: Hamden, Conn.
desc_terrain: Slightly high, but generally flat land.
favor_influences: Convenient to places of employment and a small central shopping center.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: This is a newer development containing an equal number of one and two family houses, both on fair sized plots. Houses and grounds are kept in good condition and show pride of ownership.
source: See explanations
name: Hamden, Conn.
desc_terrain: Land sloping downward from the south and becoming flat.
favor_influences: Attractive and new development.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: This is a section of small homes ranging from bungalows to two story dwellings built quite closely together. Pride of ownership is in evidence. Rental demand in this area has continued to be good.
source: See explanations
name: Hamden, Conn.
desc_terrain: Wooded land sloping toward the lake.
favor_influences: Convenient to small central shopping center.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: This is by far the finest residential section in New Haven proper. Homes are extremely large and modern. In many instances grounds approach estates in size and are beautifully landscaped. Extensive back yards and undeveloped land offers a barrier between this and the less desirable area to the west. Smaller homes are entirely owner occupied and the few large ones appearing in the rental market can only be rented at far less than carrying charges. There is no predominating rental.
source: See explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Fairly high ridgeland which is well wooded.
favor_influences: Attractiveness and convenience of location.
detr_influences: None, save lack of room for further expansion.

notes: This is one of the most desirable residential sections in the suburbs of the City of New Haven. Dwellings are both large and modern and grounds are sufficiently large as to approach estates. Landscaping is excellent and pride of ownership is of the first order. Extensive back yards and undeveloped land acts as a barrier between this and less desirable area to the west. The small homes are 100% owner occupied; larger ones rent at almost any price but income does not cover carrying charges. Consequently, there is no predominating rent.
source: See explanations
name: Hamden, Conn.
desc_terrain: High ridgeland which is well wooded.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of development.
detr_influences: None.

desirability: Stable, but to apartments on Whitney Ave.
notes: This is a section of fairly large homes located on proportionately sized lots with a tendency towards apartments on Whitney Avenue. Properties are well cared for and there is a definite pride of ownership in evidence. Livingston and Edward Streets are slightly more desirable than the remainder. This area is not looked upon with too much favor by lenders because of size and age of dwellings and the thinness of the sales market.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low land rising slightly to the north and with tree lined streets.
favor_influences: Conveniently located.
detr_influences: Trend to apartments, particularly along Whitney Avenue.

notes: This is an older section of the city containing a mixture of singles, doubles and apartment houses, with no type predominating. A number of the singles have been altered into two family houses and apartments. Plots are of fair size and generally well kept. The area rates a high "Yellow".
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Flat land with tree lined streets.
favor_influences: Convenient to center of city and Yale University.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of dwellings.

notes: This is an old and fairly congested section of the city containing a mixture of one and two family houses, now entirely occupied by mechanics in nearby factories. Area rates a low "Yellow". Loans are difficult to procure.
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Convenient to center of city and places of work.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of buildings.

notes: This is a very old section of the city given over to the working classes. Dwellings include everything from singles to multi-family. There is a scattering of manufacturing plants. Homes are built very closely together and a large portion of this area is highly congested. Pride of ownership is entirely lacking. Absence of market plus vandalism has resulted in some demolition.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Convenient to places of employment.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of development, encroachment of industry as well as character of neighborhood and occupant.

notes: This is an old section of the city containing closely built dwellings varying from singles to multi-family. A number of the old, large singles have been converted into doubles. Properties along the shore line are even less desirable. It is difficult to procure mortgage money in this area.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low, flat land rising only slightly from the river.
favor_influences: Convenient to places of employment.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of dwellings as well as smoke from the railroad.

notes: This is an older section of the city now occupied largely by workers in nearby factories and brick yards. Houses are of moderate size. Plots in some instances are large enough for small gardens. Pride of ownership is noticeably lacking. Lenders exercise great care in the selection of loans in this area.
source: See explanations
name: Hamden, Conn.
favor_influences: Nothing but adjacent park.
detr_influences: Character of improvement and occupant and smoke from adjoining railroad yards.

notes: This is a new, speculative development of moderately sized homes and lots, of which the only vacancies are those remaining unsold. Architecture is very pleasing and pride of ownership is excellent. Vacant hillside land separates this from less desirable area to the southwest. There is competition among lenders to place money in this section.
source: See explanations
name: Hamden, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of development and convenience of location.
detr_influences: Somewhat unattractive outlook together with lack of sewers and stores.

notes: This is an old section of the city containing closely built dwellings varying from singles to multi-family. A number of the old, large singles have been coverted into doubles. Properties along the shore line are even less desirable. It is difficult to procure mortgage money in this area.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low, flat land rising only slightly from the river.
favor_influences: Convenient to places of employment.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of dwellings as well as smoke from the railroad.

notes: This is a very desirable, residential section. Whereas some are of fair size the majority of homes are both modest and modern. Plots, in proportion to dwellings, are well landscaped and cared for. Larger homes almost never appear in the rental market. It is considered to be a good area for mortgage money.
source: See explanation
name: Hamden, Conn.
desc_terrain: Hillside land sloping to the lake.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: This is an exceptionally fine residential area containing nothing but large, expensive homes on extensive plots. The latter are well landscaped and there is a distinct pride of ownership in evidence. Mortgage lenders favor this area becuase of the stability of the owners, but the market for such properties is almost nil.
source: See explanations
name: Hamden, Conn.
favor_influences: Extremely attractive location.
detr_influences: None, save distance from city.

notes: This is an exceptionally fine residential area containing nothing but large expensive homes on extensive plots. The latter are well landscaped and there is a distinct pride of ownership in evidence. Mortgage lenders favor this area because of the stability of the owners, but the market for such properties is almost nil.
source: See explanations
name: North Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Extremely attractive location.
detr_influences: None, save distance from city.

notes: This is a very desirable, residential section. Whereas some are of fair size the majority of homes are both modest and modern. Plots, in propertion to dwellings, are well landscaped and cared for. Larger homes almost never appear in the rental market. It is considered to be a good area for mortgage money.
source: See Explanations
name: North Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Hillside land sloping to the lake.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: This is a small new development. Architecture is pleasing but construction is cheap. The homes are small but located on plots of fair size. Because of character of construction, lenders are none to eager to place money in this section.
source: See explanations
name: North Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Pleasant outlook.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city and lack of sewers.

notes: This a sparsely settled section which is slightly more desirable in the north. Dwellings vary from small bungalows to some of fair size. In many instances, plots are sufficiently large to provide for truck gardens and vineyards.
source: See Explanations
name: North Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Generally flat land, wooded in parts.
favor_influences: Considerable room for expansion.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city and lack of sewers.

notes: This is a sparsely settled area containing small homes located on fair sized plots; many of which include small gardens. Homes, for the most part, are cheaply constructed and pride of ownership is spotty. Loans are hard to obtain.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Good transportation and room for expansion.
detr_influences: Character of improvement and occupant.

notes: This is, generally, an older section containing a wide variety of dwellings ranging from bungalows to three and four family houses. Plots are generally small and pride of ownership is decidedly spotty. there are a few streets in the north, near Fairmont Park, that are slightly more desirable. Lenders report that care should be exercised in making loans in this area.
source: See explanations.
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Generally flat land which, in the north, rises from the river and becomes rolling.
favor_influences: Convenient to industrial section.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of improvement.

notes: This is a sparsely settled section of small shacks. Lots include gardens and vineyards. The neighborhood has no value except to those desiring to raise crops.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Convenient to places of employment.
detr_influences: Character of development and inhabitants.

notes: An area in which the predominate range is from small to moderate sized singles, but in which there are a few doubles. Plots are of proportionate size and fairly well maintained.
source: See explanations.
name: East Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Not too far from places of employment.
detr_influences: Character of neighborhood.

notes: This is an area ranging from bungalows and one and one-half story dwellings to homes of fair size. Plots are not extensive and pride of ownership is generally in evidence.
source: See Explanations
name: East Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of development and adjacence to small, shopping center.
detr_influences: Inconveniently located and lack of sewers.

desirability: Downward, due to soot from factory.
notes: This is an area of all year round houses of the better type. Lots are of a fair size and pride of ownership is generally evident. Higher valued homes are owner occupied and do not appear in the rental market. Despite attractiveness of location, the area suffers at times from soot from a large manufacturing plant immediately to the northwest. This objectional feature limits mortgage money.
source: See Explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Land rises from the water to the west and becomes swampy to the east.
favor_influences: Attractive outlook.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city and smoke from nearby factory.

notes: This is an area originally built for summer use only, but most of the homes are now used all year round. Pride of ownership is spotty. This area rates a high "Yellow".
source: See explanations
name: New Haven, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractive outlook.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city, lack of sewers and danger of flooding.

notes: This is an area of small houses many of which are bungalows. Plots are generally small. Area is a typical beach resort, largely occupied only during summer months. Along the shore, particularly to the west, the homes are more desirable than elsewhere. this section, generally, is only sparsely developed.
source: See explanations.
name: East Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low, flat land which is wooded in parts.
favor_influences: Beach location.
detr_influences: Inconcenience of location and lack of sewers.

notes: This is a sparsely settled area containing bungalows and small singles. Although lots in some instances are smal, many are of sufficient size to include gardens and vineyards. Construction is exceptionally cheap and area rates a low "Yellow". Lenders do not favor this section.
source: See explanations
name: East Haven, Conn.
desc_terrain: High, rolling and partially wooded land.
favor_influences: Room for expansion.
detr_influences: Character of development and inhabitant.

notes: A new and highly restricted residential area built around a golf course. It is partly within the city and partly within the town. Dwellings are of varied but attractive architecture, located on plots of substantial size. Homes range from more modest to extremely large. These latter never appear in the rental market.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of development and its convenience of location.
detr_influences: Lack of sewers and necessity of traversing undersirable section of the city to reach location.

notes: A somewhat newer development containing homes of modest size and of varied but pleasing architecture. Plots are small but well cared for. There is no topographical or other barrier between this and the far less desirable area to the east, save a hill.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Land rises sharply to the north and west.
favor_influences: Desirability and convenience of location.
detr_influences: Possible spread of undesirable element from the east and south.

notes: In this generally densely populated section is a mixture of old and new housing varying from singles to multi-family and all built closely together. the area is now given over to the city's undesirable element. There has been just completed a slum clearance project at Richmond Hill. Institutionally owned properties in this section are being dumped for whatever they will bring.
source: See Explanations
name: Stanford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Rolling land rising to the north.
favor_influences: None, save convenience of location.
detr_influences: Character of occupant and improvement. Institutional dumping.

notes: This section contains a number of cheaply constructed dwellings of varying size ranging from bungalows to two-family homes. Those in the south are somewhat newer but those in the north are of fair age. On West Avenue, between West Main Street and Selleck Street, are a few Negros. Also on Ardmore Road.
source: See explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Land rising to the north and wooded in setions.
favor_influences: None
detr_influences: Character of development and ocupants

notes: This quite thickly populated section contains a mixture of 1, 2 nd 3 family dwellings, most of which are built closely together and are of substantial age. They serve to house factory workers in the adjoining industrial area. There are a few scattered plants within the section itself. There are a few colored families along the railroad and on Crosby Street.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
favor_influences: Convenient to center of city and places of employment.
detr_influences: Encroachment of business and industry

notes: This is an old section of the city. Houses are of fair size, generally, though plots are small. Quite a few in the southern portion have been converted into two family homes. Pride of ownership is spotty. There are a few Negros on Franklin Street, Washington Avenue, and Woodside Street.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Land generally flat and wooded, particularly in the north.
favor_influences: Conveniently located.
detr_influences: Age and obsolescence of dwellings.
build_type: Singles - a few converted into 2 family

notes: Within this area there is a considerable variance in type and size of structures; all being located on plots of proportionate size.
source: See explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Well wooded land rising to the north and there becoming rolling. The northern portion lies within the town and beyond the city limits.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of locaion.
detr_influences: None, save lack of sewers beyond the city limits.

notes: This was formerly an area of large, old estates. A number have been broken up for development purposes. Today, this section contains a mixture of old, large estates and small, modern homes on plots of proportionate size. It is, therefore, impossible to arrive at any predominating value or rent. Estates are either owner occupied or closed up; there being no demand for same.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: None.

notes: There is a wide difference in both size of home and property. They range from small dwellings to estates and there is an equal variation in their age. A few of the very large homes have been closed and these represent practically the only vacancies. In the southwest corner there are a few, modern apartments.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Wooded land rising to the north. At least half of this area lies beyond the city limits in the Town of Stamford.
favor_influences: Convenience and attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: None, save lack of sewers beyond the city limits.

notes: The majority of homes and plots are small. Architecture, though somewhat varied, is not overly pleasing. There are also not a few homes which are far less desirable than the average and becuase of this, the area should rate a "low blue".
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Slightly rolling land and generall well wooded. All of this area lies beyond the city limits and includes the two small villages of Springdale and Belltown; each having its own small shopping center.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location
detr_influences: Distance from center of city and lack of sewers.

notes: This land is largely owned by the Phillip's family whose plant lies in the adjoining industrial area to the north. North of Glenbrook Road, they constructed for themselves several very large and attractive homes. On the land to the south, they have built a number of modern, small and attractive homes which they rent.
source: See explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location and improvement.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city.

notes: The majority of properties in this area comprise small dwellings located on plots in proportion. There are, however, a few large new homes owned and occupied by some of Stamford's leading citizens but not in sufficient quantity to alter the grading of this section. There is one negro family on Courtland Hill Terrace.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Wooded land rising from the water and river to the west and becoming rolling. The northern and southern portions lie beyond the city limits within the Town of Stamford.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city, stores and schools. Lack of sewers beyond city limits.

notes: In the northwest are found a mixture of old, one to three-family homes. In the southeast, homes are somewhat newer and a number are of the bungalow type. There are a few Negros in the Cove Section.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Generally flat, low land which rises slightly in the north.
favor_influences: In the west, convenience of location and in the east, frontage on Long Island Sound.
detr_influences: Character of improvement.

notes: This is an old, residential section for the most part containing large homes of substanial size and age. Not a few of these are closed up and unoccupied. Because of the desirability of the location, it is safe to assume that, evantually, these old dwellings will be replaced by modern, new homes ultimately changing this to a "first grade" area. High land values should prevent any further decline in desirability.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: Necessity of traversing undesirable sections to reach this area.

notes: This is a highly desirable and well restricted section of summer homes, which is operated almost as a club. A gate and guard prevent undesirables from even entering the area. Dwellings are of varying size and architecture is pleasing. Plots are largely extensive.
source: See explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Wooded land rising slightly to the northwest and forming a point in Long Island Sound.
favor_influences: Restrictions and desirability of location.
detr_influences: Necessity of passing through undesirable sections of the city in order to reach this area.

notes: This is an old section of the city which now approximates a slum area. Dwellings are built closely together and vary from singles to multi-family units. Institutionally owned properties in this area are being sold for whatever amounts they will bring.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
favor_influences: Convenient to center of city and places of work.
detr_influences: Character of neighborhood and occupant. Institutional dumping.

notes: This is largely devlopment of cheap, small bungalows which, because of price, has attracted an undesirable element. In the eastern portion, almost all cellars are flooded during periods of high water.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Low, flat land in the east which is higher in the west.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: Character of improvement and occupant. Eastern portion is subject to floods.

notes: This is an older section largely devoted to summer homes although some are occupied the year round. Most of the dwellings are of fair size although plots are generally small.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Wooded land rising from the water to form a central ridge.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: Necessity of passing through undesirable setions to reach this area.

notes: This is one of the best known summer residential sections in the neighborhood of New York City and has been for a number of years. Dwellings vary from the modest to those of substantial size. Architecture is varied but pleasing. Owing to high land values, plots are not extensive, yet of sufficient size.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Land rises from the water forming a central ridge. Area is well wooded.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of lcoation and its improvement, as well as zoning restrictions.
detr_influences: Necessity of traversing undesirable sections of the city to reach this area.

source: J. E. Townes Bank of Commerce
name: Richmond, Va.
desc_terrain: Generally flat. Rolling enough for drainage.

notes: This is a highly restricted residential area containing summer homes of New York business men. Dwellings vary from the modest to those of considerable size with lots in proportion. Vacant and somewhat swampy land forms a natural barrier between this and the less desirable area to the north.
source: See Explanations
name: Stamford, Conn.
desc_terrain: Flat land extendig out into the Long Island Sound.
favor_influences: Zoning restrictions and attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: To reach area, necessity of passing through undesirable sections of the city.

notes: This is a small town of greater than the average attraction. This particular section contains, for the most part, dwellings of substantial size and estates - the summer homes of wealthy New Yorkers. There are, however, a few small homes.
source: See Explanations
name: New Canaan, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location, improvement and occupant.
detr_influences: None, save lack of sewers.

notes: This is an older, residential section containing in its center, a small shoppping district. Homes are entirely single family but of varying size and are located on proportionately sized plots.
source: See Explanations
name: New Canaan, Conn.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of a small town and containing a small shopping center.
detr_influences: Lack of sewers only.

notes: This is a slightly older and sparsely settled section in which most of the homes are of moderate size and generally lcoated on proportionate plottages. Open fields separate this section from the hazardous one to the northeast.
source: See Explanations
name: Darien, Conn.
favor_influences: Character of improvement and occupant.
detr_influences: Inconvenience of location and lack of sewers.

notes: These are two old sections in the heart of the town which have been given over to the laboring class. While one family dwellings predominate, there are also a number of two and three fmaily.
source: See explanations
name: Darien, Conn.
favor_influences: None
detr_influences: Character of occupant and improvement.

notes: This is a sparsely setled section which contain cheaply constructed, small, frame homes; a few of which are of the bungalow type.
source: See Explanations
name: Darien, Conn.
favor_influences: Convenient to small shopping centers in the Villages of Noroton Heights and Darlen.
detr_influences: Character of improvement and lack of sewers.

notes: This is a somewhat older and sparsely improved section containing a mixture of large and small homes on plots of proportionate size.
source: See explanations
name: Darien, Conn.
favor_influences: convenient to small shopping area in center of section.
detr_influences: None, save lack of sewers.

notes: In general, this is a sparsely settled section; although a few scattered portions are fairly well built up. The majority of the homes are of a fair size, modern and of attractive architecture. Many, particularly those along the Post Road, approach estates in size. Almost all are occupied only during summer months. A wide arterial highway- the Boston Post Road- separates this from the less desirable area to the northest.
source: See explanations
name: Darien, Conn.
desc_terrain: Land is flat along the water's edge and to the north becomes rolling. Most of the terrain is well wooded.
favor_influences: Attractiveness of location.
detr_influences: Inconvenient to stores and shopping center as well a lack of sewers.

notes: This small area is the only portion of a defunct "Boom-Time" subdivision in which houses were erected.  The remaining portion of the subdivision consists of vacant lots heavily overgrown with various types of tropical growth.  Repair condition of property ranges from fair to poor.  Due to the distance of the subdivision from the center of the city, and poor maintenance of lots, some authorities felt that from a desirable residential standpoint, this area should be graded "high D grade", rather than "Low Yellow".  The HOLC has one property in this area.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Level flat heavily wooded land.  Area contains about 10 houses.

notes: This subdivision was developed during the "boom".  Good restrictions, and since the depression has shown little sales activity and some new construction.  Houses in the area range from $5000-15,000.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn & Hope, Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B. Green, President of John B. Green, Inc., realtors also personal inspection of Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as Jungle Terrace.  Land level and flat.  Area contains about 18 houses.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential and medium restrictions well enforced.  Adjoins golf course.  Major streets paved.
detr_influences: Distance from city - about 6 miles.  Area sparsely built up.  Vacant lots poorly maintained.

notes: Value of estates in northern portion of this area range from $50,000-100,000 and are occupied by both the winter residents and one or two retired business men.  Southern half of area is vacant with lots owned by wealthy individuals
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn & Hope, Inc., HOLC Contract Brokers; John B. Green, President of John B. Green, Inc., Realtors, also personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Land level and flat.  Water frontage.  About half of area improved with 5 large private estates

notes: Most of the houses in this small area were built prior to the boom, hence are of the one and two-story frame single type.  Fair repair.  Range in price from $4000-7000.  This area is surrounded by Jungle Terrace Golf Course and a better grade and type of residential property.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: This small area, known as the older portion of Jungle Terrace, is level and flat.  Area contains about 10 houses.

notes: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold.  This is spotted area containing some property in good repair, some in poor repair; containing some one-story single, some two-story single, some comparatively new homes (7 years), and some old houses (about 25 years old).
source: Mr. R.L Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as older portion of Pasadena. Land is level.  About 55 houses in area.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Street car transportation along Central Avenue.  Grade school in area.
detr_influences: Sparsely settled; distance from center of city (6 miles).  Septic tanks used chiefly.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots during entire year.
inhab_type: Principally retired executives, business and professional men
salesdemand2: Two story singles at distress prices

notes: (a) Ample motgage funds available, but on a restricted basis.  About 45 houses in the area.  During the boom, lots in this area sold from $5000 to $10,500 each, but can now be purchased at tax foreclosure for about $250 a lot (75 ft. to 100 ft. frontage).
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC Contract brokers; John B. Green, President of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as Pasadena.  Land is level.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential and highly restricted.  Overlooks Boca Ciega Bay.  Street car transportation facilities.  Near school and church.  All streets paved.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city - 6 miles.  Sparsely built up subdivision poorly kept, from appearance standpoint.  Defunct promotional project which is now tied up in litigation and various other claims including heavy tax accumulations and heavy paving assessments.
inhab_type: Business men and retired business men and executives
peakrent: Not rental area; practically no rentals in area

notes: This area consists of two subdivisions.  Residential restrictions are well maintained.  There has been no new residential construction and a few sales made in recent years in the area.  Houses in the area range from $5000-15,000.
source: Mr. R.L Hope, president of Thorn & Hope, Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B. Green; President of John B. Green, Inc., Realtors; also personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Level, flat land.  About 15 houses in area.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Good restrictions.  Streets paved and street car transportation facilities available within two blocks of area.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city - about 6 miles.  Sparsely built up.  Vacant lots poorly maintained.
inhab_type: Local business and professional men & retired business men

notes: This outlying area consists of several different subdivisions built during the boom and which have since shown little sales activity or new construction.  Half of the area is inside the city limits of Gulfport, hence the property in same is subject pending financial reorganization as the municipality recently entered bankruptcy.  Practically all the houses in the area are one-story singles ranging in value from $3000-5000.  Most of same are in fair repair conditions.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Level flat open land.  Contains about 45 houses and is sparsely built up.

notes: This area contains a cheap type of residence ranging in value from $1500-3000 majority of which are in fair repair conditions.  The property in this area is subject to pending financial reorganization as the municipality recently entered bankruptcy.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Level flat low land containing about 15 houses in the northern portion of the area, and about 10 houses in the southern portion.  Practically all of the area lies within the city limits of Gulfport.

notes: Most of this area is within the city of Gulfport and is subject to pending financial reorganization.  (Municipality now in bankruptcy.)  Occupants of this area are skilled mechanics and families of small income.  Repair condition of properties range from fair to poor, and values of same from $1000-2500.  Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida

notes: 1935 population of incorporated community of Gulfport was 1,036 or about 260 families and houses.  Considerable resistance among tenants and prospective purchasers against living in Gulfport.  Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold.  Refunding of city's heavy bonded indebtedness will probably be accompanied by scaledown of both principal and interest.  Cheap type of tourist occupies this area during winter.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: Gulfport, Florida
desc_terrain: Main portion of Gulfport.  Land is level.
favor_influences: Southern portion of area fronts Boca Ciega Bay.  Street car transportation facilties.  All streets paved.
detr_influences: About 7 miles from center of St. Petersburg.  Practically unrestricted and little or no zoning.  Infiltration of lower grade population.  Municipality recently entered bankruptcy under terms of Wilcox Law.  Heavy growth of weeds throughout entire year on vacant lots.

notes: A few of the cheaper type of tourists live in this area during the winter season.  Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as Tangerine Avenue section.  Land is level.  Extreme western portion inside city limits of Gulfport.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Schools, churches, and business center in area.  Street car transportation facilties.  Majority of streets brick or rock paved.
detr_influences: Restrictions have either expired or are not enforced.  Considerable distance from central business center.  Arterial traffic conditions along Tangerine Avenue.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots during entire year.  Small groves and farms spotted throughout area.
inhab_type: Clerical workers, skilled mechanics, farmers & laborers

notes: This area adjoins Negro area "D7" on the west, hence the eastern portion of "D14" does not contain a particularly high grade of white occupant.  Small groves and farms spotted throughout the area. Most of the houses are of cheap frame construction in fair to poor repair condition.  Range in age from 1 to 25 years old.  Value of houses in the area range from $500-1000.  Properties, if acquired in this area, should be sold.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Land in this area is level, open, and flat.

notes: ** from gas plant (not particularly detrimental to type of occupant in area).  Creek through area gives off odors and provides breeding place for mosquitoes.  Septic tanks used principally.  Wells used instead of city water, due to high cost.  Fire hazard because of cheap type of construction and crowding of houses.  Arterial streets only ones paved - 10%.  Difficulty of collections.  Moderate amount of vandalism.  Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold.  Sixty percent of the property in the area is unencumbered.
source: Mr. W.A. Majors, leading agent for St. Petersburg negro rental property; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Southside negro section.  Land is mostly level, with some lowland.
favor_influences: Parks, recreation centers, schools, churches, and business center for negroes in this area.
detr_influences: Majority zoned for light industrial.  Unrestricted.  Between 3rd and 7th Avenues and 11th and 14th Streets South there is a filled in area - formerly an old lake; consequently, water supply from wells in this section is contaminated and property in this sub-area has been condemned by the city because of fire hazard.  Odors**

notes: There is an inferior grade of property in area between 11th and 17th Avenues South, etween 4th and 6th Streets, which should be rated as "D" grade.  Sacttered throughout the area are occasional blcoks of property which are a slightly better grade or type of property than that in the remainder of the area; the largest such sections within the area are in the extreme southeastern portion (the largest, between 1st Street South and Beach Drive and between 19th and 22nd Avenues South; the second largest, between 14th and 16th Streets South and 12th and 14th Avenues South, which small sub-area consists of only a few blocks of new houses - one story, $5000-7000 singles).
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B. Green, president of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Area contains Roser Park and close-in south side section.  Land is level and area is traversed by Booker Creek.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Street car transportation facilities.  Presence of junior high and grade schools and community business centers.
detr_influences: Portions of area unrestricted, and in other portions restrictions have expired.  Moderate income group predominates.  Arterial traffic along Ninth Street.
inhab_type: Cheap tourist class, clerical workers, and skilled mechanics

homebuy: Ample, but on a restricted basis
homebuild: Ample, but on a restricted basis
desirability: Downward for desirable residential; upward for commercial purposes.
notes: While this area is similar in many respects to C2, the improvements are considerably older and are not in quite as good repair condition as those in C2.  (a) Large apartments and hotels eliminated.  This is a rooming house area in transitional stage from residential to commercial.  Property in this area, if acquired, and if city continues to grow, justifies a holding rather than a selling policy.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Close-in southside rooming-house section.  Land is level.
favor_influences: Proximity to center of city, waterfront and tourist activities, parks and recreation centers; churches within area.  Practically all streets 100 ft wide and paved.
detr_influences: Adjacent to airport.  Unrestricted and zoned for apartment houses, rooming houses, hotels, and multiple family dwellings.  Heavy vehicular traffic and noises of same.  Encroachment of rooming houses continue.
inhab_type: Mixture, principally winter tourists of all types

homebuy: Ample but on a restricted basis
homebuild: Ample but on a restricted basis
notes: There are several large misplaced expensive homes in this area and a small sub-area (between 21st and 25th Avenues South and 14th and 17th Street South) containing a fairly uniform type of property which is of a slightly better grade than that in the remainder of the area and should be classified as "B" grade property.  Property, if acquired, in this area should be sold.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B. Green, president of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Good street car transportation facilities.  Bartlett Park in northern portion of area.  Presence of schools and small community churches.
detr_influences: Restrictions expired or not enforced.  Distance from city - 2 miles.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots in most of area, even during winter.  Some unpaved streets.  Tourist camps in the area.
inhab_type: Business men, clerical workers, skilled mechanics and laborers.
fam_income: 750-2500; This income range covers 90% of the area's occupants

notes: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold.  This area contains considerable spotted property which individually would be classified as "B" grade, were it not for the fact that the area is so sparsely built up.  Southern portion of this area (Lakewood Estates) was heavily promoted during the boom, but has shown little activity since 1926.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as Lakewood Estates and Bayou Bonita.  Land is level with eastern portion of the area having been artificially made (sand pumped in from Bay)
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Schools and community business center.  Majority of streets paved.
detr_influences: Restrictions have expired or are not enforced in most of the area.  Inadequate transportation facilities.  Sparsely settled.  Distance from center of city (4 miles).  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots during entire year.  No gas facilities.  Mosquitoes more prevalent than in any other area in the city.
inhab_type: Professional men and clerical workers; retired; business men

notes: This subdivision was developed during the "boom" with intensive promotional effort.  But most of the activity was in vacant lots rather than homes.  The area adjoins the Lakewood golf course, which is well maintained and the few houses erected in the subdivision are two-story stucco singles ranging from $8000-15,000, most of which are in good repair condition.  Only a few of the streets are paved and there is little demand for property in this area.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: This subdivision is known as Lakewood Estates, contains about 10 houses and is high level and fairly well wooded.

homebuy: Limited and on a restricted basis
homebuild: Limited and on a restricted basis
notes: Very few tourists in this area.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B. Green, president of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as West Central section.  Land is level.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Street car transportation through center of area.
detr_influences: Only small portion of area is restricted.  Lack of schools, churches and community business centers.  Sparsely developed and settled.  Distance from center of city.  Some infiltration of lower grade population.  Heavy growth of weeds even during winter.  Unstable type of occupants.  No sanitary sewers; septic tanks
inhab_type: Clerical workers, skilled mechanics and laborers

notes: Many occupants of this area are truck farmers, skilled mechanics, and laborers, consequently, income is unstable and irregular.  Poor repair condition of houses in area graphically illustrates this condition.  Values of houses range from $600-2000.  Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Level, flat, open land.  Most of it is used for vegetable farms and truck farms.

notes: Occupants in this area belong to lower income group, and majority of properties have small gardens which provide additional income for owners through the sale of vegetable and citrus fruits.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Comparatively high level land.  Area contains about 35 houses and numerous small citrus groves.

notes: Value of properties in this area range from $1000-4000; repair condition of some ranges from fair to poor
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Level flat open land with very few shade trees, and is sparsely built up with cheap type of improvement.

notes: About 20 houses in this area; contains a cheap type of house in poor to dilapidated repair condition.  Incomes of occupants are unstable and irregular.  Property, if compared to this area, should be sold.  Value of the property ranges from $300-1500.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida

desirability: Static with some upward tendency at present time
notes: This area was developed during the boom, but experienced little activity thereafter until 1931 and 1932, since which time the presence of the $1,000,000 senior high school has acted as a strong drawing card for the area, particularly among families with children.  In 1931 and 1932 houses from other areas of the city were moved into this area and have since been thoroughly reconditioned and are now in good repair.  (a) Due to the fact that homes are now being constructed in the area are of a better type and grade than the area possessed prior to the depression
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC Contract Brokers; John B. Green, President of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as High School section.  Land is level
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Only senior high school in the city is located in this area.  Street car service on two sides of area.  Majority of the streets are paved.
detr_influences: Some of the streets are rock-surfaced only.  Low building restrictions.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots.
inhab_type: Local business men, clerical workers, and some skilled mechanics
pop_inc: At the second fastest rate in the city

desirability: Static with slight upward tendency due to influence of school within area.
notes: Had this area not contained a considerable number of properties whose age and type of construction indicated rather rapid depreciation in the future, the area would have been classed as a spotted B area.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn & Hope, Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B. Green, President of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as High School section.  Land is level.
favor_influences: Proximity to $1,000,000 senior high school.  Served by street car line.  Practically all streets are paved.  Fairly close-in section.
detr_influences: Majority of area is unrestricted.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots during summer.  Mixture of social classes.
inhab_type: Mixture; local business men, clerical workers, skilled mechanics, retired business & professional men

notes: No tourists in this area.  Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold.  Unfurnished rental units predominate in this and the remaining "D" areas, although there is little difference in actual net return to owner of unfurnished properties compared with furnished properties, because former type is unusually rented on an annual basis, whereas furnished type is usually rented on a seasonal basis and remains vacant between seasons.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Fairly close-in near street car transportation faciltiies and within walking distance of high school and grade school.
detr_influences: No restriction.  Southern portion near railroad and highest industrial area.  Infiltration of lower grade population.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots in summer.  Difficulty of rental collections.  Proximity to negro area.
inhab_type: Clerical workers, skilled mechanics and laborers

notes: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold.  Sparsely developed area containing about 100 houses; area not related to St. Petersburg area from tourist standpoint.  More of an agricultuiral community - several dairies in area.  Population of this incorporated community is about 400.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: Finella Park, Florida
desc_terrain: Land is flat, level, undeveloped pine land

notes: Most of the sales and rental history shown on D3 also applies to this area.  Same is occupied by similar type of population - poor grade white.  Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Land ranges from open, flat to well wooded.
detr_influences: Lack of zoning.  Practically no restrictions.  No gas facilities or sanitary sewers.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots.  Difficulty of rental collections.  Cheap type of improvements, and poor repair conditions of sames.
inhab_type: Skilled mechanics, laborers & cheap type of tourists

notes: This si generally known as the lowest grade white section in the city.  Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as Pine City.  Land is level.
favor_influences: Accessible to schools.  Bus transportation facilities.
detr_influences: Lack of zoning and practically no restrictions.  No gas facilities or sanitary sewers.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots.  Difficulty of rental collections.  Cheap type of improvements and poor repair conditions of same.

notes: Lots in this area are improved with cheap type residences which are occupied by low income group.  Values range from $1000-2500, repair conditions range from fair to poor.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Level flat wooded land sparsely built up with about 20 houses.

notes: In the northern portion of this area, houses erected during the boom were moved during the depression into C1 and B3 near location of million dollar high school in B3.  Southern portion of area is badly spotted and contains a few houses of shack type.  Value of the houses range from $1500-5000.  There has been no residential construction in the area since the boom and practically no sales.  Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Northern portion of this area level, flat, open land having similar characteristic to D8.  About 30 houses in area.

notes: Lots in this area are in most cases improved with cheap flimsey type of houses.  (This applies only to northern portion of area).  Prices of houses in this area range from $1500-4000.  Repair condition is fair to poor.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B Green, President of John B Green, Inc., realtors; anjd personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida

rentdemand1: Practically no rentals in this area
notes: About 30 houses in this area.  Wide range in family income is due to the fact that quite a few wealthy families live in the area; some of them are local, while others are out of state residents who own homes in the area and occupy same during the winter season. (a) This subdivision was developed by an individual who built most of the houses in the area; consequently, present stability of the area is due largely to his personal sales effort and unusually substantial type of construction.  Upon his demise, future trend of desirability will be doubtful.  This is an unusually well developed subdivision (about 80 acres) in which restrictions and types of construction are of the highest grade and have been rigidly enforced since the subdivision opened.  New homes  have been built in this area steadily since the collapse of the boom in 1926.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC Contract Brokers; John B. Green, President of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by field agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
favor_influences: Street car line to edge of area (used principally by servants).  Zoned for residential and highly restricted.  Methodist Church in area.  All streets paved.  Well landscaped.
detr_influences: Distance from center of city (3 miles).  Surrounded by cheap type of property, occupied by mediocre type of inhabitants.  Area has poor outlook to north and east.  Heavy weed growth on vacant lots during summer.  Poor approach to area.
inhab_type: Executives, business men, retired business men and professional men
build_constr: Stone on hollow tile 50%, stucco on hollow tile 50%

desirability: Static for next few years, then slowly downward with age of properties.
notes: Property along Ninth Street zoned for neighborhood business - (business "A") Extreme northeastern portion of area is sparsely developed and the few houses in the section are of cheap type of construction.  This portion of the area also contains large orange grove.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC contract brokers; John B. Green, president of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Portion of Euclid section.  Land is level.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Street car transportation facilities.  Presence of schools, small churches, and neighborhood business center.
detr_influences: Restrictions in many of the older subdivisions have expired.
inhab_type: Mixture: Local business men and clerical workers; retired business and professional men

notes: Well laid out subdivision with straight and circular streets; uniformly paved; houses of good type.  Restrictions rigidly enforced until expiration of same several years ago, by which time enforcement of city building and zoning ordinance assured continued high class development; 55 houses in area  (a) Due principally to new construction in the area.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC Contract Brokers, John B Green, President of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent.
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as Woodlawn.  Land is level.
favor_influences: Zoned for residential.  Most uniformly developed area in St. Petersburg.  Well landscaped.  Bus line serves area.  Near grade school (5 blocks).
detr_influences: Practically none.
inhab_type: Local business and professional men, retired business men
pop_inc: Faster than any other area in city

notes: This area was developed prior to and during the boom, then lay dormant until 2 or 3 years ago, since which time there has been  considerable construction in the area and a good demand for vacant lots, the area getting more than its share of new construction.  About 65 houses in the area.  The wide range of family income in this area is due to the presence of wealthy retired winter tourists who own homes in this moderate priced area.  (a) Due to construction of new homes in the area since the low.
source: Mr. R.L. Hope, President of Thorn and Hope, Inc., HOLC Contract Brokers; John B. Green, President of John B. Green, Inc., realtors; and personal inspection by Field Agent
name: St. Petersburg, Florida
desc_terrain: Known as Crescent Lake section.  Slopes eastward to Crescent Lake.
favor_influences: Adjacent to Crescent Lake and Crescent Lake Park (city park).  Within three blocks of street car on Ninth Street.  Zoned for residential and moderately restricted.  No schools, churches, or business center in area (asset for this type of resident).  All streets paved.  Well landscaped.
detr_influences: Heavy weed growth on vacant lots during summer.
inhab_type: Executives, business and retired professional men
